ERICH BRADLEY CONRAD, EXECUTIVE VP, TREASURER & HEAD OF IR, CARDTRONICS PLC: Good morning and welcome to Cardtronics2019 Investor Day. I'm Brad Conrad, the company's Treasurer and Head of Investor Relations. Thank you to all of you attending here in New York at the NASDAQ market site, and thanks to those who are joining on our webcast.

Before we get started today, a couple of quick administrative items. First, today's program will last approximately 3 hours and will conclude at approximately noon Eastern. We will have a brief break at 10:15 this morning for about 15 minutes, and we will conclude today's program with a question-and-answer session at approximately 11:30. Please hold your questions until that time.

And I'd like to first start with a statement before we start today's program. During the course of the presentation, there will be forward-looking statements within the meaning of the safe harbor provisions of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. Forward-looking statements often address our expected future business and financial performance and often contain words, such as expects, anticipates, intends, plans, beliefs, seeks or will. Our information in this presentation is based upon our current expectations as of the date hereof unless otherwise noted. Our actual future performance and financial performance may differ materially and adversely from our expectations expressed in any forward-looking statements. We undertake no obligation to revise or publicly update our forward-looking statements or this presentation for any reason. Although our expectations and beliefs are based on reasonable assumptions, actual results may differ materially. The factors that may affect our results are listed in certain of our press releases and disclosed in the company's most recent Form 10-K and 10-Q, along with other public filings with the SEC. In addition, today's presentation includes certain non-GAAP financial measures as defined under SEC Regulation G. The reasons we believe such measures are useful, together with a reconciliation of those measures to the most directly comparable U.S. GAAP measures, have been included in the appendix of the presentation.

And with that out of the way, I'd like to welcome Ed West, our Chief Executive Officer. Thank you.

EDWARD H. WEST, CEO & DIRECTOR, CARDTRONICS PLC: Thank you, Brad. Good morning, everyone, and welcome to our, I think it's actually the company's first Investor Day. We're really glad that you're here and we're actually quite excited to share with you the story that what all we have been working on for the last 1.5 years. What I'm going to do is kind of kick off and walk through the agenda and then kind of introduce the team that you're going to be hearing from.

Joining me today with the company is our entire executive team. Frankly, our whole team is relatively new over the last 2 years in the company. I'm going to kick off and go through a strategic overview of what we've been focused on, what we see ahead of us and what that will mean to all of us as owners of the company.

Then I'm going to turn it over to Brian Bailey. Brian joined us about 2 years ago and is now Head of Managing Director all of our commercial operations in North America. Brian joined us after a 22-year career at NCR where he most recently was Head of their -- globally Head of all their FI Products and Solutions.

Also joining Brian is Brad Nolan. Brad heads up our Allpoint Solutions for the business. Brad also joined us about 2 years ago, and came from a 20-year career with JP Morgan Chase where he most recently headed up Branch Automation Technology and Strategy.

Following a quick break, Marc Terry, who is our Managing Director of International which are all of our markets outside of North America. He heads up the commercial activities in those various countries. He will hit on that, go into some detail about where we see the business going in each of these markets. Mark joined us from FIS where he was the Managing Director for at EMEA at FIS. Previously, he was the Managing Director of VocaLink in the United Kingdom after a carrier with ACI Worldwide.

Then I'm going to turn it over to Gary. Many of you all know Gary Ferrera, our CFO joined the company after I moved Nolan to CEO. Gary joined us from DigitalGlobe where he was CFO there up until the company sale and then prior to that he had been CFO of 3 other companies.

As I mentioned, the rest of the management team is here. I really encourage you to meet with the team during the intermission or afterwards. Also, pleased to announce one other member who is not here today, but will be joining the company in about a month will be our new Chief Marketing Officer. Paul Wilmore who is most recently CMO of Barclays in U.S.A. and Head of Barclays' Barclaycard and credit card businesses for the last -- has about a 25-year experience within the card business and brings a lot of great expertise for partnership in B2B2C businesses, which we'll be talking a little bit more why that's an important hire going forward.

So let's jump in. Basically, what we have here is a plan on the page. There's a lot that's been going on over the last 1.5 years. We've been very focused on driving durable organic growth in the business. We're evolving the company from a legacy ATM deployer to a self-reinforcing network-based business going forward. We've been investing heavily in new products, enhanced products in the business, all informed based on multiple conversations with financial institutions around the world. We believe that these new and enhanced products, combined with our end-to-end platform that we have today as some of the leading retailers scale and experience, will enable us to tap into an evolving secular trend in consumer financial services. We believe that trend and that market is roughly a $15 billion market that we will be able to tap into. These solutions that we've been working on make us very viable with financial institutions of all sizes, whether a community bank or the largest bank in the land, a FinTech or BigTech, all drive significant value and also very importantly, as do our core leading retailers around the world. So all parties participate and win with these solutions. Now the way we're going to approach this $15 billion market through a combination of that self-reinforcing network as well as enhanced managed services capabilities for financial institutions. That, combined with growth that we see in certain European markets, we believe will lead to long-term durable revenue and earnings growth for the company. Ultimately, what will evolve are is -- our locations will become physical-to-digital kiosk serving a broadening set of financial services transactions at a leading retailer near you. Now what we're going to do is get into how we're going to do all those different matters.

But for those of you who are new to the story, little bit of background. Cardtronicshas 25 years of experience, started up in Houston, Texas. Today, we operate in 10 countries around the world and each of the markets that we operate have a little bit difference in characteristics and market dynamics affecting each one of those. We believe our medium-term growth will largely come from North America, centered in the United States and also markets such as Spain, Germany and South Africa, we expect to see a significant amount of growth. Markets like United Kingdom and Australia have been going through a lot of change. Based on different variables in each country, specific amount of change leading to re-optimization of operations here but we're beginning to see the size of that stabilizing and believe that these markets too will return back to growth.

In all of these markets, we are either the #1 or #2 leading independent deployer of ATMs in each of those countries and that's an important fact. Some other factoids I think are very interesting, which we'll talk more about today, we're in 8 of the top 10 retailers in the United States. We are convenient, tens of thousands of locations, top convenience in the U.S. There are over 60 million card members who participate in Allpoint and frankly, most of them don't even know it. We see that as an opportunity.

Next, 2.5 billion transactions a year, we transact over our platforms on over 200,000 ATMs. We have scale and we have significant experience. And finally, we have relationships with over 2,000 financial institutions around the world. That is a significant opportunity with an installed set of customers. All in all, what does this mean? It means that we participate in a 2-sided network between financial institutions and retailers on either side with global scale and significant experience and convenience.

Now a year ago, I outlined a set of priorities for the company and what we're going to be focused on and what the new management team would be driving towards. First and foremost, drive durable organic revenue growth. The company has a long history of driving organic growth, but also a lot of M&A. What we decided is we need to focus and execute on integrating our operations and upgrading our capabilities, developing new systems, products and enhancements to open ourselves up to a new market and needed to get focused. Second, operational excellence and portfolio optimization. How we're bringing these platforms together, integrating together so that we can drive scale and operating leverage in the business and also result in better customer experience who better controls, the mantra is scalable, repeatable, driving standardization across the business. Third, creating raving fans with our customers. I just talked about a phenomenal installed base. We -- there is a lot of opportunity, the more we can do in having those customers becoming bigger and bigger fans of our organization, the more we can expand just within that installed base, but also referrals to new customers. Fourth, generating employee pride. We have a purpose-driven mission and our employees know it. Working with communities around the world and supporting cash transactions. We want Cardtronicsto be a place where folks are proud of to move up into their careers at the company and finally, delivering on our financial commitments, delivering significant free cash flow.

So what was the report card. How did we do? First, this past year we turned the company North America back to organic growth. 2017, organic growth was a negative 2% and 2018, we moved that in North America to a positive 4%, really centered by the growth in the United States. Second, we had double-digit surcharge-free growth in our surcharge-free network in the U.S. this past year. And we had double-digit growth in our growth countries of Spain, Germany and South Africa.

Operationally, we returned back to ATM, our availability came up to record levels. We want to thank Stuart MacKinnon over here, who is our CIO and Chief Operations Officer. We integrated our technology and operations, new software, rolling out capabilities, enhancements, integrating the platforms for record availability. What did that result in? More ATMs up running, happier customers and better results to the bottom line. We optimized the fleet. We look at every ATM around the world in terms of its own profitability and contribution and we're putting it to the highest and best use that led to the pull out of Poland, redeploying those resources to Germany, to Spain where we get back into growth and making more money and cash flow in those markets. But that doesn't stop there. We are all over the world, whether it's been Australia, United Kingdom, the U.S., every market we go through to optimize our network and portfolio. We rolled out our ERP. And finally, it's something we're very proud of, our Allpoint solution based on independent survey from Walker rated Allpoint as Truly Loyal based on feedback from our customers with Allpoint.

And finally, financially, we exceeded the expectations that we outlined at the first of the year, throughout the year and how we ended up the year. We had significant free cash flow. Our free cash flow is up nearly 60% on a year and ended up over $100 million, all of which we used to pay down debt for the company and now on a glide path to getting back into our targeted leverage levels, which I'll talk about in a minute.

Now a lot of you all had questions over the time thinking about revenues and just having a better understanding, looking at our various revenue types. So what I thought would do is quickly walk through 3 different views within our revenue. First, you see on here is geographic. Over 60% of our revenue is centered in North America. Obviously, the lion share of that is in the United States. Next look is by our ATM type, around -- in terms of our ownership of the ATMs. So we have over 230,000 ATMs that we operate. Over 88% of the revenues that we generate come from those ATMs that we own. This shows the average number of ATMs, the 77,000. We ended the year with roughly about 75,000 being deployed. 88% of our revenues for the year came through those that we own. And the third area, a way of view of looking through the business comes into by the type of customer experience that's happening at the machine. So on the left-hand side, you will see about 41% of our revenues are generated by customers who are on a surcharge-free basis, meaning they're going to get their money and not being charged for that and it's free to the consumer. Secondly, 50% of our revenues come on a surcharge basis, meaning they go to the machine and they pay a convenience fee to access their money. And the third way, 9% of that is through managed services. Now what I'd like to do is drill into these 3 areas a little bit more and give you a little bit more visibility each into those 3 categories. So again, 41% surcharge-free and this is on a global basis, 41% surcharge-free we call that in the U.S. In the United Kingdom, we call that free use. And globally, we're about 50% on a surcharge and 9% managed services.

Now let's drill in. And probably, the best way to look at what are the different sources and types of revenues that are coming into, let's look at a particular ATM. Obviously, we're here in the U.S., so we're going to focus on the view from the U.S. business, which is our largest segment, country. And let's just take a look at the closest ATM nearby. So type in looking at the NASDAQ market, what is our closest ATM to where we're sitting here today through the eyes of Allpoint. So we want to find out what's the closest using our Allpoint locator, what are the closest ATMs and we see within a several block radius there are about 10 locations that are all within walking distance. We've got just surrounded and covered of a convenient ATM. In fact, we got all of America covered, 83% of the population is within 5 miles of one of our ATMs. If we look at right here, the closest one, which happens to be right across the street at the Walgreens, what do we find? What we find is this ATM. It's branded, it's branded with Citibank. If we go to that CVS, which was a block and a half away, we see a different branded ATM where we own the ATM and is branded with Santander on that. So let's say I am a Citibank customer coming in and want to access my cash through that branding relationship, I personally can go in access my cash for free and withdraw that. Our revenue stream on that through branding institutions is a fixed monthly payment based per ATM on a monthly basis to allow those customers to access the ATM at no charge. In addition to it, the financial institution also pays us a per transaction fee every time one of their customers. So it's a combination of both the fixed monthly payment per ATM plus a per transaction fee.

The person behind that at the Walgreens, maybe an Allpoint customer. That Allpoint customer, say perhaps, I bank with either Capital One or USAA, both Allpoint customers, that individual comes up is also able to probably use their locator app, which is embedded in the financial institution to access and find that machine, go in there, use that for free. Our revenue sources on that are multiple, different types. The financial institution can either pay us a fixed monthly rate based on having network access to our ATMs for all of their card members or they can pay us on a per transaction basis. So the FI can pay either a fixed basis based on having broad network access on their total number of cardholders or on a per transaction. In addition, we receive interchange on that. And so the interchange goes to the ATM owner or deployer and obviously we deploy the majority and significant preponderance of the network -- Allpoint network ATMs so the majority of that interchange comes to us.

Now behind that person could be a surcharge. So who is going to come in, wants to access, walk in here of the Times Square, wants to access cash at the ATM and he will pay a convenience fee for that. In addition to, in the United States, we would also receive interchange from their financial institution. Separately, perhaps there is an international customer behind that individual, who is coming in from another country, visiting, wants to get some U.S. dollars at the machine. They too pay that same convenience fee plus we would receive international surcharge. And in addition to we'd have the opportunity for a DCC transaction should they want the peace of mind in understanding what the amount being withdrawn is in local currency we could do have -- they could choose to have a DCC transaction.

So as you can see at that one ATM right across the street we have multiple different sources of revenue to come into that, whether it's on a surcharge-free basis, branding, Allpoint, surcharge basis, multiple different types coming at a single ATM. We would call that a network ATM. It is our goal to continue to try to drive working with financial institutions and FinTechs of the like to drive more and more traffic to this type of experience.

The third area, going back to that by pie, was in managed services. Over 130,000 ATMs that are under our managed services relationships. The vast preponderance of those, over 130 -- about 130,000 are retailer merchants who are ordering -- processing their transactions at their ATM and all our platforms are processing. We're the largest processor of ATM transactions in the free world, big benefit there in processing those transactions. Those are long-term arrangements and that they have variable per transaction type rate. What we see growing now is several thousand ATMs that are on full-managed services basis, basically outsourcing of an ATM fleet with a financial institution.

With those, and an example here was PenFed, where a PenFed, which is one of the nation's largest credit unions, we manage their estate of 135 ATMs around the world. We're held to SLAs, performance levels on that and we're honored to serve their customers. And under any of those types of relationships with typically a long-term arrangement, more of a fixed pricing nature with some variability. Again, what we see there in the managed services is a growing market, adding long-term more contractual revenue.

Now what's going on in the marketplace, what's new? Some of you may say, Ed, there's been changes going in banking and FI for a long time. There's nothing really new. We spent a lot of time, one of the favorite things I like to do is getting out with the sales team and meeting with customers and prospects and understanding what's working, what's not. There's a lot changing in the marketplace. What's changing is the big banks and the regional banks are on the move. They're moving into new markets, they're looking for more customer growth, they're looking for more deposits and they're going into new markets all over the country in the U.S.

Separately, what that means for the incumbents who have an installed base there. They are being threatened. They need to drive better efficiency ratio. They need to drive their cost down. They need to at presence. There is big larger banks coming in overnight, quick access to a large catchment area in a particular market. The incumbent institutions need to defend their area. In addition to that, you have FinTechs and BigTech who are coming into markets, but they're doing it in a nontraditional way. They're going direct to the consumer, bypassing the traditional rails into the market, and with the digital native, and mobile experience, and going directly to the customer, and they are doing that on a national way. So there's a lot happening and changing in the marketplace. What's the common element in all of those? Customer growth, customer engagement and a relentless focus on efficiency ratio. Everybody has to drive their cost down. And what does that force? It forces a mindset of how do I reprioritize my investments and my resources to the highest and best use in terms of what's core to me. This thesis holds true for every financial institution in the land. They have to reprioritize their resources to where the consumer is and what they're desiring is that mostly the digital and mobile experience. If you look at the most recent example with the announcement with SunTrust and BBT. One of the chief reasons they put out on that is to get to scale and get the technology, and be able to invest more resources in technology. And what they need to do is move out of what's not core. We would submit, and I think financial institutions are increasingly recognizing what's not core is managing an ATM estate and managing that cash infrastructure, one of the big services that financial institutions have provided at the branch for a long time has been that cash infrastructure. Now they're increasingly recognizing that, that's not core. But you know what? It is core to us and we do that in a larger, more scalable, in a lower cost than many institutions all over the world.

So how has this been coming together? How has this been looking and manifesting itself? If you look in the United States, in the last 10 years, branches have declined by about 10%. And frankly, over the last couple years, the pace of decline has accelerated at a record level. This same phenomena holds true in almost every country in which we operate. In the United Kingdom, over 800 branches closed the past year, a significant increase in the number of closures. In the United Kingdom, the number of ATMs are now below 70,000 ATMs. Same fact in Australia. This will drive 45% of our midterm growth. Now let's discuss some of the drivers of margin expansion. As I mentioned earlier, we have cycled through the loss of a high-margin retailer, and we'll be cycling through LINK interchange reductions throughout the year. These declines in revenues pressured margins even with significant mitigation efforts. Returning to revenue growth, we'll provide natural margin leverage, which will be even more accretive as we drive incremental transactions across the existing asset base. We'll also continue our focus on operational excellence by continuing to optimize the fleet, continuing to integrate systems and processes as well as many other initiatives. These multiple levers will allow us to grow adjusted EBITDA in excess of revenue growth.

We'll now turn our focus to capital investments. Over the last few years, we have invested approximately 50% of our capital towards growth, and we expect about a 50-50 split in 2019. The remainder of capital investment is focused on maintenance and infrastructure development. This has ranged between 3% to 5% of revenue over time.

Our reduced growth capital investment in 2018 was driven by fleet reallocation, for example, when we moved machines from Poland to Germany as well as use of warehouse inventory post 7-Eleven. Normalizing for this would have resulted in closer to a 50-50 split we have seen recently and anticipate in 2019. 2019 investments will be driven by enhanced functionality, new product and new placements.

Now let me summarize our medium-term outlook. Based on what you've heard from the team about the strength of our network and product offerings, combined with the market backdrop, we believe a revenue goal of 3% to 5% is achievable. The combination of this top line growth and the resulting natural operating leverage, along with a company-wide focus on operational excellence, should drive 7% to 9% EBITDA growth. Finally, we will continue to focus on disciplined capital allocation, resulting in annual CapEx investment of approximately 8% to 10% of revenues. As we've mentioned throughout the day, we anticipate achieving these results organically. No acquisitions are assumed in this outlook.

Most likely, these would include programmatic share repurchases and/or dividends. As Ed previously mentioned last evening, we announced an opportunistic share repurchase program of $50 million. Keyword here is opportunistic.

And this also gets back to why, as I mentioned earlier, bringing the Chief -- the CMO into it and thinking about the B2B2C. Today, our teams are working through this and having a dedicated focus how we're working there enhancing that awareness and further penetration just among that installed base. We love to bring in, and we will continue to bring in new relationships, but just expanding more on that install. And Bob, you had a...

ROBERT PAUL NAPOLI: Just on the North America growth, the bank branding and surcharge-free, is -- or bank-branding Allpoint, is that a double-digit growth business? I know you had double-digit transactions, but are you -- to get to mid- to high-single-digit North America growth, maybe break that down, same-store sales, bank branding, surcharge-free revenue growth would be helpful.

GARY W. FERRERA: Yes, I mean, we haven't given out that detail. And when you think about it, I mean it's -- we go out to the solution provider, Brian and his team, when they're meeting with people. So to get specific as to whether it'd be Allpoint deposits, Allpoint+ or something else, we're not providing that information right now.

ROBERT PAUL NAPOLI: But you would expect the bank branding in Allpoint to be the fastest growth piece of it? And is there pricing compression, or is it just mix related?

GARY W. FERRERA: No. I don't think it's pricing compression. But yes, we expect those to be high-growth areas.

ROBERT PAUL NAPOLI: Okay. And then just a follow-up on the U.K. I mean, that's still a big market for you. Do you expect growth to resume in the U.K. in 2020? And how has the shift gone? I mean the strategy there, you've taken a number of ATMs from free-to-use to pay-to-use, how is that going and do you expect more shift in the U.K.?

EDWARD H. WEST: Sure, yes. So just stepping back, I mean the U.K. obviously has been going through a lot of change based on the pricing changes to the broad-based free-to-use environment, which was established in change because of LINK's actions. And as Marc mentioned, the second of those actions took place just this past quarter in January, so the market is still digesting that. We've been proactive on that. We pulled capacity based on those changes, where you may have had a marginal performer, now is not performing, so we pulled it out of the market. Others that we fear were going to be better on a pay-to-use basis and have been going through that conversion. We believe through this year, the market should stabilize, through this year and see what the implications are, and then we'll move forward from there. I think the kind of the concern for the country, frankly, has been the disruption to this terrific free-to-use environment for the citizens of the United Kingdom. And that's having an impact in particular in the rural communities, not as much on High Street because you have multiple, but even to some degree there because the banks are continuing to pull their ATMs, but in particular in those rural communities. And that's where we're also working on different solutions to help support those communities, working with government, working with LINK, working with financial institutions and trying to do other things to help support those areas. We'll come back to you all and talk about more and see what all develops and advances. But I would just say sitting here today, we have a pretty sizable headwind, obviously, this year. But just like we muscled through the actions with 7-Eleven we'll soar through. Marc and the team in the U.K. have been a terrific job, reworking some of the network, our position and we'll see how the back half of this year performs out and then from these pilots and also the rule and report back.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And if we could go back to the managed services part of the business, a couple questions just to understand that better. What would you consider your sweet spot? Like what number of ATMs does a bank or a credit union have that you would say this is a really sweet spot for Cardtronics and this is where we could win? I mean who do you consider your competitors? And maybe just one more on that, how do banks look at the return on investment when they look at trying to outsource. So maybe start with the bottom and...

EDWARD H. WEST: Brian, you want to jump in on it?

BRIAN JOSEPH BAILEY: Yes. In terms of the sweet spot, I think our current customer base has trended primarily between 50 and 150 ATMs, that's sort of the target market we've been successful with. In any sale of managed services, it's a strategic enterprise decision for an FI to outsource their channel. So whether it's a top 10 bank or a top 200 bank, the time and effort and diligence it takes to make that sort of selection takes time. Our sales process, our business value calculators and our operational readiness is better than ever. So we are shrinking our sales cycles down, but in many cases, these are long stage sort of relationship development. Going forward, we do expect to be able to service customers with up to 500 ATMs, right. So we think we can go upmarket a bit, but also we're more excited as well to go down market. How do we make this offer consumable to banks with less than 20 ATMs? We have to do it in a very different way, very clean, very crisp and very programmatic, but we think that also is a value proposition for us. So that's where we've been spending our time, and I think the teams have been very successful today, and we have an increasing pipeline of activity across our managed services opportunities.

UNIDENTIFIED PARTICIPANT: And just the competitors, who would you consider your competitors?

BRIAN JOSEPH BAILEY: Competitors. Yes, so we are -- as we talked about today, our end-to-end platform is very unique in the industry. We see competitors who do a portion of what we do. They may supply technology, they may supply break/fix maintenance, but very few can offer that end-to-end capability in a business that wakes up every day thinking about ATMs. There's a number of companies that offer the end-to-end, but it's a very minor, small part of their business, where they're not innovating and investing in the technology like we are. So we've been very lucky. When we can get a customer to that decision to truly outsource the managed services, we've been very successful with our win rates.

EDWARD H. WEST: I just want to emphasize the point Brian was making. When we first really started rolling this out in the U.S. and focusing on it 1.5 year ago, it was around that sweet spot, that has broadened out and, as just mentioned, up to 500 or even lower. What we're talking about in the longer term, that number will continue to get larger as we bring more and more onto our platform and a disciplined rollout and interest level from financial institutions. So we look at that total market opportunity as -- and Brad mentioned in his comments, we see even going up to the largest financial institutions for their off-premise locations. And this has just been a disciplined rollout, and we're having conversations with all sized institutions now. Let's take one last question. Any others? I think I may have been -- Bob -- we're going...

ROBERT PAUL NAPOLI: Bob Napoli from William Blair. One last one. Just you put out there a TAM of $15 billion, and I assume that's a North -- I think that was a North America or U.S. TAM. I was just wondering how you built up to that TAM? And what do you think that TAM is going to do over the next few years?

EDWARD H. WEST: Sure. So that TAM is a total of $15 billion, we showed on that slide, looking at the whole market, what we believe that that will look like by the year 2022. So 5 years out, as this grows for that whole 5. The way we get there is by taking a very detailed look of how -- what we think the market from an approach based on solutions that are out there, whether that would be through a surcharge-free network, whether that would be through managed services, whether it's withdrawals or deposits looking at multiple different solutions, getting very detailed into that, and the total number of transactions. And as Brad talked about, what we see actually overall is a decline in some of those ATM transactions or withdrawals but the growth because of coming off of the teller. So we've taken all those different approaches added up, and then that's how we get to the $15 billion.

Thank you all. Thank you very much for a terrific discussion, and we look forward to keeping you posted. And thank you, again, for your support of Cardtronics. Good day.

urn:contentItem:5DNT-K7R1-JCMN-Y2FY-00000-00Careful what you wish against: Silicon Valley just rolled out a red carpet to government regulation2014-11-24T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisCareful what you wish against: Silicon Valley just rolled out a red carpet to government regulationSarah Lacy

Nov 24, 2014 (PandoDaily:http://pandodaily.com Delivered by Newstex)
It may seem from the outside as if Silicon Valley repeats the same boom and bust cycle over and over again. In fact, at peak performance, the Valley is like a self-healing organism that assiduously learns from its mistakes. During the most recent cycle, following the great dot-com collapse of 2000, the Valley almost corrected itself out of a repeat disaster.

This time around, the consumer Web boom almost had it all. Almost. But Silicon Valley greed and ego just couldn't help itself. And that may have drawn attention from a very unwelcome quarter: The government. Consider two of the things that made the dot-com crash so disastrous, and contrast them with the market today: First, the market for online services has grown astronomically. In the late 1990s, the hyperbole about the Web changing everything was totally true, but ahead of its time. The result: Valuations bore no relation to the underlying businesses that bore them. This time around the valuations are no less shocking, but in many cases (Uber, above all), there are real businesses supporting them - huge businesses that serve sometimes more than one billion people around the world. Second — and more key — is a decreased reliance on public markets. Back in the late 1990s, success and IPOs were synonymous, and frequently companies needed the proceeds from an IPO to keep the lights on and fund their aggressive expansion plans. But that was part and parcel to the dot-com undoing. Public market investors bid these stocks up aggressively amid the pre-crash hype, and then, because they were outsiders with no vested interest in the success of the companies they owned, sold them off just as willingly once the bottom began to fall out. One reason the crash was so devastating is that it wasn't just insiders who had money at risk, it was everyday folks. Companies who were stuck being public but managed to survive the reckoning had other problems. They had to rebuild businesses in a harsh glare of demanding investors wanting quarter-to-quarter results. Look at what Yahoo — a company that once lead the Internet in eyeballs — has endured since the crash. To this day, it's never gotten out of the quarterly muck long enough to put together a plan to regain its relevance to the critically important young online audience of today. Today, successful companies are staying private longer, and only facing down the inevitable public market scrutiny once they're large and mature enough to survive the bright lights. But it wasn't an overnight change, it was one that happened in stages, led by the example of the hottest companies of each generation. Public enemy 'Hacking' is more than just coding in the startup world. Hacking is a way of life. You hack your mental energy — apparently — by putting grass-fed butter in your coffee. You hack getting fat while programming all day by getting a treadmill desk. You hack dating with a mobile app or retirement planning with a robotic investment advisor. Naturally, in the wake of the crash, everyone wanted to hack the IPO. The industry wanted to find a new way to reward VCs and investors for taking all that risk, without punishing their companies by casting them out on their own too early. Acquisitions weren't the answer because (until lately) the price tags weren't big enough. More startups exit today by acquisition than IPO, but some 95% of the returns[1] for the industry still come from the massive, massive home runs generated by about 5% of the deals, and these are almost always IPOs (WhatsApp notwithstanding). As the venture industry has swollen in size, those home runs need to be massive to keep everyone paid and provide the lifeblood essential to starting the next generation of companies. Acquisitions typically don't do that. Also, many entrepreneurs want to build something that will last. Very few acquired companies do well with new overlords. The hack came in via a combination of secondary markets — which allow select early investors, founders. and employees to cash out well before an IPO — and a insane multi-billion dollar swell in late stage private investment activity. This capital is coming from the kind of investors who — in another era — would be buying shares at the IPO. Facebook was really the company that first hacked this process — a move I've previously described[2] as the Web 2.0 era's equivalent of 'The Netscape Moment.'
Like a lot of people in the Valley, I thought this was mostly a positive development. After all, it means founders are able to sell shares earlier, aligning their interest with more diversified investors so that everyone wants to 'go long' together. Big sustainable companies investing in making our lives better, creating wealth, and jobs are all good things, right? A long term focus is always better than a short term focus. An obsession with short term is, after all, why industries like newspapers and the recording industry and Detroit Auto are flailing now. They all saw the future but couldn't really act on it.
I also — naively — thought companies in the hands of professional (private) investors would yield better results in terms of products and growth than companies in the hands of the activist hedge funds, short-term oriented traders, and skittish ma and pa mainstreets that make up the majority of public market investors.
This is where I - along with many, many others - was wrong. Completely wrong. I never thought I'd write these words: Sometimes the public markets is the best thing that can happen to a hot company.
How it all went too far The move to hack the IPO has happened in three acts, which can be traced to three seminal companies: Google, Facebook, and Uber. Each was the company of its era in the Valley, so despite being outliers, as the most visible home runs, they set the tone. Coming out of an era where companies were going public in 18 months or less, Google pushed the IPO off until it was a strong enough company to control its own destiny. It took a lot of the power out of the hands bankers by insisting on a dutch auction and it was one of the first big tech companies to have dual stock structures meant to insulate management from outside threats. Then Facebook pushed the envelope further, but not only implementing a dual stock structure, but by also allowing a lot of people to exit before the IPO — hoping the IPO would be less of a singular defining liquidity event. (That didn't totally work.) Today, Uber running a different playbook than even Facebook. First, it has controlled access to liquidity much more than Facebook ever did. But, by contrast, the company's access to capital has been an exaggeration of Facebook's already prodigious fundraising path. Uber has wholly embraced the notion of raising gargantuan amounts of money at jaw-dropping late stage valuations as an avenue to put off an IPO, seemingly indefinitely if it wants. That should suit a CEO like Uber's Travis Kalanick who bristles at anyone telling him how to do his job and hates government regulation. Importantly, Uber is the first unicorn of the mobile-first era. It led the wave of expanding the consumer Web into the real world, and with it drummed up totally new and lucrative business models. It's a company that has gotten big fast, and despite operating in a highly regulated part of the world, it's done so with little oversight. Enough is enough Watching the various scandals of Uber unfold this week[3] I was struck by two things. The first is that there is seemingly no line the company's executives can cross that will make the board or investors act. The second is related: It's the first time I've ever felt like a private venture-backed company's product and customers would be better off if that were publicly traded. Imagine the last week if Uber were publicly traded. Imagine Wall Street's reaction to reports that it's 'god viewing[4]' journalists data and proposing $1 million campaigns to target their families with 'oppo research' splashed on every network, the front page of the biggest three newspapers, and even the butt of late night talk shows[5]. Public investors have sold off at far less. The public markets may be driven by emotion and fear, but it's a market that is also highly efficient at holding companies accountable for bad behavior and forcing change when needed. The public and the press have spoken, with the clear message from the majority being that as a society we don't think this behavior is OK. But Uber's investors have exerted no pressure on the Valley darling. Instead, they're sitting around, waiting out the news cycle or, in the case of Ashton Kutcher, actually joining in the smears[6]. Finally, two days into the farce where we were expected to believe Emil Michael's comments at a private party didn't reflect his actual beliefs, and worse expected to believe that Uber as a company didn't support those views even though it refused to fire him, there was only one force that could act: The government. Washington comes to Silicon Valley Enter Senator Al Franken's letter to Travis Kalanick[7]. This is the second — and far more dramatic — time we've seen something like this in the venture world the last few weeks. When The Guardian reported[8] concerns over Whisper's use of consumer data, the executive seemingly responsible, Neetzan Zimmerman, was initially not removed from his job either. Again, the investors seemed to be nowhere to be found. And so we got a letter[9] from a senator: Senator Jay Rockefeller in this case. Thanks to changes in how companies are funded and the free flow of capital across the venture ecosystem, founders in Silicon Valley exert more control than ever before. Also, truly huge consumer hits are so rare that once in, investors are terrified at pissing the founders off and locking themselves out of more ownership, or torpedoing their golden goose by speaking out against its bad behavior. Again: More founder control should be a good thing. But left totally unchecked and you wind up with… Uber. As Joe Nocera from the New York Times wrote[10] this weekend, 'At Uber, the inmates are running the asylum. That needs to change, while there's still time.' The message from Senators Franken and Rockefeller is equally clear: If Silicon Valley VCs refuse to keep the behavior of their portfolio companies in check, the government will. For companies, this is very bad news because the government doesn't remotely understand technology or business. You thought the SEC was a pain in the ass? Now the regulations aren't only interested in financials, but at companies' uses of customer data - something that directly affects product road maps and the ability to monetize all those precious eyeballs. I find myself in a position I never thought I'd be in watching this week's events unfold: I'm actually glad to see the government taking a closer look at Silicon Valley. Reckless disregard for customers — even when customers are now uninstalling Uber in droves — has left senators little choice. Someone has to act in public interest when these technology companies are controlling highly sensitive information - in this case, information pertaining to our movements around a city that directly impacts the safety of everyone getting in these cars. Travis Shrugged That Uber might end up being the company that brought Washington regulars to Silicon Valley is richly ironic, given Uber is known as the poster child[11] of the libertarian disruption movement. You won't hear me say this often this week, but I don't entirely blame Travis Kalanick for what's going to happen next. I blame Uber's investors and its board. They are supposed to be the arms length reality check on an impassioned, semi-crazy founder. They are supposed to be the ones with all the pattern recognition to warn for unintended consequences. And they are the ones who should be long-term greedy not short-term terrified of missing out on the next round. Uber's investors failed the company this week. They failed their LPs whose money they invest. And they failed this industry, which is fighting to outgrow its reputation as a place where immaturity and machismo more rule than exception. For once, Silicon Valley should be thankful to see the government intervene. It may be the only thing that keeps this whole train from barreling off the tracks. Sarah Lacy Sarah Lacy is the founder and editor-in-chief of PandoDaily. She is an award winning journalist and author of two critically acclaimed books, "Once You're Lucky, Twice You're Good: The Rebirth of Silicon Valley and the Rise of Web 2.0" (Gotham Books, May 2008) and "Brilliant, Crazy, Cocky: How the Top 1% of Entrepreneurs Profit from Global Chaos" (Wiley, February 2011). She has been covering technology news for over 15 years, most recently as a senior editor for TechCrunch.

Trump's relationship with Carl Icahn is one of mutual respect and admiration between the two billionaires. Donald Trump sees Carl Icahn as an insider ready to help overhaul the economy. On the campaign trail, a Donald Trump joke about Hillary Clinton's views on gun control is attracting controversy. The U.S. markets closed slightly higher on Tuesday. The NASDAQ is at a record high. China has warned the United Kingdom their relations will suffer if the British government goes ahead and drops plan for a $23 billion nuclear power plant. British Prime Minister, Theresa May, has announced a review of the Hinkley Point C Station. Pogba is returning to Manchester United. The deals are ready drawing criticism because of the huge amounts of money involved. Michael Phelps will swim to regain glory on Tuesday night in the 200-meter butterfly final. Phelps has made it clear, he's not going just for gold. The leaders of Russia and Turkey say their strained relationship is easing. Vladimir Putin and President Tayyip Erdogan announced new economic initiatives and increased defense cooperation at a meeting in Russia. Several Fox News personalities and producers have told CNN they long feared that Roger Ailes had tapped their phones to monitor conversations. A short time ago four new cases of the Zika virus have been reported in Florida. Hillary Clinton, during her visit to Florida, has called on the Congress to return to Washington and pass legislation to fight the Zika virus. Brazilian homeowners are competing with hotels and cashing in through Airbnb.

[16:00:00] RICHARD QUEST, CNN HOST: Closing bell ringing on Wall Street, the Dow Jones Industrials having had gains in the morning evaporated in the end. That's it, you show us how it should be done. A strong gavel bringing trading to a close. It is Tuesday, the 9th of August. Tonight, Carl Icahn says Donald Trump will be up there with the great presidents. The billionaire investor is on this program, coming up.

A Russian reset. Vladimir Putin says he'll restore ties with Turkey.

Also tonight -- better the red devil you know. Manchester United breaks a world record to resign Pogba. I'm Richard Quest, tonight from Washington D.C., where of course I mean business.

Good evening. Donald Trump's new economic plan has received its highest profile backing so far. In his first tweet about the U.S. presidential election in more than a year, the billionaire activist/investor Carl Icahn is hailing Mr. Trump's speech as great. He then went on to praise Trump's temperament for persevering as protesters interrupted throughout Monday' event. And Carl Icahn asked his twitter followers, the following question, "How many of our presidents, even our great presidents, would have handled the antics that went on in that auditorium as well as he did?"

Now Trump's relationship with Carl Icahn is one of mutual respect and admiration between the two billionaires. Carl Icahn has consistently praised Mr. Trump's promises to renegotiate trade deals. Donald Trump sees Carl Icahn as an insider ready to help overhaul the economy. Even at one point suggesting that he could serve as his treasury secretary. At a campaign rally in June, Donald Trump said he wanted Icahn to take a lead role in renegotiating America's trade deals.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, U.S. REPUBLICAN PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATE: I'm all for free trade. It's fine. But I want Carl Icahn negotiating for me. I want the greatest business people negotiating my deals, not hacks, OK.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

QUEST: Carl Icahn joins me now on the line. Mr. Icahn, thank you, sir, we're glad and grateful you have joined us this evening. Let's begin. You described the speech as great. And obviously you put Donald Trump as potentially one of the great presidents if he's elected. What is it about Mr. Trump that you find so appealing?

CARL ICAHN, ICAHN ENTERPRISES CHAIRMAN, DONALD TRUMP SUPPORTER (via telephone): Yes, well, I would just like to clarify. I said the way he handled the problems, the disruptions, I thought he did it in a very cool way. But as far as I'm concerned, the economic system today is very flawed. And I think we have a great problem in our economy. I've been saying that for, you know, a year or two. You can't have a government at war with business. You can't have a government at war with business. And this is what we have today in our country.

I think Donald spoke to that in his speech at some great length. I think one of our major problems in this country is the fact that you have a regulatory agency sort of running amok. Now, there are good people in them. There's got to be regulation. There's got to be a system. But I'm going to be speaking about that in the future myself. You don't have capital spending. I mean, spending for machinery, spending for factories. We don't have that today. And we are at an all-time low as far as productivity goes. We don't really manufacture products anymore.

QUEST: Right.

ICAHN: As far as I'm concerned, I think this economy can go -- basically could go over the precipice.

QUEST: Now, let me jump in there, if I may, sir. Donald Trump has also criticized business in his own right. He criticized Ford for sending jobs, what he said was to Mexico. He talked about Apple building their phones overseas.

[16:05:00] He's blasted hedge funds and Wall Street in many ways, the establishment, if you like. And so how do you balance that, if you like, with the criticism that you say of the Obama administration against business? Donald Trump has also been highly critical.

ICAHN: I don't think he's -- let's start with -- there's a difference in what you're talking about. In his trade policies, I haven't studied them greatly. I'm no expert on trade. That I leave to Donald and his economic advisers. As far as the fact that we don't have jobs, he claims, he says, and I think there's a lot of truth in it, because of very bad trade policies and trade agreements. But the area that I'm focusing on more, which I think is really abominable, is the fact that we really are, as a country, as a business, as people that own businesses -- America is really made of business, we're a capitalistic society.

I think that today business is afraid of government. They're afraid of what government is going to do. I don't think there's much argument about that. I could show you examples of when the EPA actually puts businesses out of business. And that's true of the NLRB, that's true of the FDC to some extent. Now, they're not bad people. But the mandate they have is basically in many ways to putting regulations that keep businesses from spending capital. Hey look, if you're the CEO of a company today, and you know and I speak against a lot of CEOs, I've been very critical of many of them, as you know.

QUEST: Absolutely.

ICAHN: But in this case, I have to agree with them. Even a mediocre CEO today. He looks at it and says, hey look, on the one hand, I have money, I can put in new machinery. And now I look when I put in new machinery and I've got an EPA that doesn't like me and is going to regulate the hell out of me and I'm not going to make money out of that investment. I can borrow money at zero interest rates, thanks to the Fed. Or I could buy the stock back. So all this money is being funneled so you think that the stimulation from the Fed would build capital in this country and give jobs to many of our middle class workers that really don't have good jobs. I don't think we can argue that.

QUEST: If I can jump in there, just to -- on this point that you raise, are you worried, though, as you put forward this pro-business argument for Donald Trump, that many in the Republican Party are actually running away from him at the moment, almost disowning him as he puts forward these proposals.

ICAHN: No, I don't really agree with that. I think he's had a very bad week, I'm not going to debate that. In other words, they don't like some things, some of the attacks he does. I think that's how he sort of won the primary. I personally would say that, hey, people who make mistakes, I think he went overboard last week. And I think a lot of Republicans don't like that. And it maybe hurts their chance to get in the Senate. But I think that can be rectified. But they're not saying -- they agree that we have -- look almost all Republicans agree, government has got way too big in this country.

And not only too big, but it's actually frightened corporate America. I think it's very simplistic. If you're frightened, if a country is frightened, they're not going to invest capital, which is what's going on. Capital spending is lower, has just gone down, which is unheard of when you're not in a recession, and our productivity is at its slowest point, growth and productivity in the third quarter we just had.

QUEST: Let me ask you, finally, sir, and we are grateful for this, would you, are you, have you thought about in any shape or form, if president Trump is elected, that you would play a role in the administration? I know early on there was talk of treasury secretary. What role would you like to have?

ICAHN: Unequivocally I will not, except maybe in the kitchen cabinet somewhere, you know, like Jackson had. In other words, there is no way. You know, I have ten businesses, 15 businesses that I run. I like doing what I do. I've been successful at it. But I do think if Trump doesn't win, and you get more of the same that you've had for the last eight years, we have a major problem in our economy. We do already, because we don't have jobs for the middle class, good jobs. And if you don't have productivity, you know, we're not Rome. If you look at Rome, they had hegemony for 800 years, but it was vastly different.

[16:10:0] The plebeians didn't have to work, because they had a great army and the army would go conquer other countries and bring in goods for nothing.

In this country we don't do that. So therefore, our hegemony will fall by its wayside if we don't produce goods. You can't keep just texting to each other. You say well great, we're a service economy. Isn't that wonderful, and for a while that works. Everybody is walking around the street texting. If you go on and on, you get to its conclusion you get more and more texting. That doesn't make an economy. And that is going to cost us dearly in the future.

QUEST: Carl Icahn, thank you, sir, for joining us on the line, I appreciate it, thank you. Your forthright views, always good to hear from you. We've obviously been digesting what Mr. Icahn said, particularly on the question that he says, quite unequivocally, that he has no ambitions to be in the cabinet. The kitchen cabinet is what he describes himself as perhaps being interested in, as he runs those. But a clear unequivocal support for Donald Trump on the business question of getting regulation off the back of businesses.

On the campaign trail itself, a Donald Trump joke about Hillary Clinton's views on gun control is attracting controversy. Sara Murray is in Fayetteville in North Carolina, where there's going to be a rally later this evening. Sara Murray, what was said and what was meant and are people taking it out of proportion?

SARA MURRAY, CNN POLITICS REPORTER: Well, that is exactly what people are parsing right now. Donald Trump made a comment about second amendment supporters and about Hillary Clinton's Supreme Court Justices. People are reading it very different ways. But it certainly raised eyebrows among those in the room and those on twitter. Take a listen.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

TRUMP: Hillary wants to abolish, essentially abolish the second amendment. By the way, and if she gets to pick -- if she gets to pick her judges, nothing you can do, folks. Although the second amendment people, maybe there is, I don't know. But I'll tell you what, that will be a horrible day.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

MURRAY: Now, the Clinton campaign quickly seized on this. They took it as a sign that Donald Trump was looking to incite violence. Clinton's campaign manager put out a statement saying what Trump is saying is dangerous. Now the Trump campaign also quickly moved to clarify this comment and they're spinning it in a different way, saying that what Donald Trump meant is second amendment supporters are going to rally behind him and vote for him in November. In their statement they said, it's called the power of unification, second amendment people have amazing spirit and are tremendously unified, which gives them great political power. And this year they will be voting in record numbers and it won't be for Hillary Clinton. It will be for Donald Trump. But Richard, this was the week when Donald Trump was trying to stick to the script. We have a number of Republicans saying they won't back him or are cautious about backing him. And it's offhand comments like these that have caused political fire storms for him in the past.

QUEST: At the end of the day do we put today's comments down to just one of those things, a here today gone tomorrow campaign foible?

MURRAY: it's always very difficult to tell with Donald Trump, Richard, because as you know, he says a lot of things in the course of the day, on television, at his campaign events, and on twitter. I do think that the one thing that is notable is how fast the Trump campaign responded in trying to clarify what he meant, saying we were just talking about people voting for Donald Trump over Hillary Clinton. This is a big change from the campaign we were dealing with a couple of months ago or even a couple of weeks ago that might have let a comment linger out there for weeks or days without any kind of explanation.

QUEST: Sara Murray in Fayetteville, North Carolina. If you get the Fayetteville right in terms of pronunciations, you'll be all right.

The U.S. markets closed slightly higher on Tuesday. The NASDAQ is at a record high. Paul La Monica is at the New York Stock Exchange. All the markets remain extremely ebullient, although, the NASDAQ particularly. So what's driving the NASDAQ more than others?

PAUL R. LA MONICA, CNN MONEY CORRESPONDENT: Yes, you have big tech stocks that continue to rally. Optimism about their earnings, companies like Google and Amazon that both hit all-time highs today, Richard. Even though there is a lot of skepticism about the health of the consumer, Google and Amazon are two companies that continue to do extremely well.

QUEST: The Dow starts -- I won't say it was rip roaring. It was up the best part of 50. The gains evaporated and we eked out a small gain. So the concern there was what?

LA MONICA: I don't know if there was a real tangible news event that whipped the market around today. Because when you look at it, at the end of the day, we were in a very tight range.

[16:15:00] This is the summer. Volume is a bit lower. But what's interesting is that there are some concerns about the health of the American consumer. Retail stocks really took it on the chin today, Gap in particular, really bad results once again. And you have to wonder now, are American consumers pulling back? Or are they just not spending at these traditional mall-based retailers because they're doing everything on Amazon?

QUEST: Paul La Monica, thank you.

LA MONICA: Thank you.

QUEST: China has warned the United Kingdom the relations will suffer if the British government goes ahead and drops plans for $23 billion nuclear power plant. The new British Prime Minister, Theresa May, has announced a review of the Hinkley Point C Station, which is a joint project between the British, the French, and the Chinese. The Chinese are China has warned the United Kingdom their relations will suffer if the British government goes ahead and drops plan for a $23 billion nuclear power plant. The new British Prime Minister, Theresa May, has announced a review of the Hinkley Point C Station providing a third of the capital. China announced its stake in the British project late last year. Then David Cameron pledged a golden era of relations between the two countries.

Now the Chinese ambassador has written to the "Financial Times" and said, "Right now the China/U.K. relationship is at a crucial historical juncture. Mutual trust should be treasured even more." Patrick Chovanec, is the chief strategist at Silver Crest Asset Management, as well as a professor at Columbia University's School of International and Public Affairs. Many wondered why the British Prime Minister would be picking a fight with the Chinese particularly when the British will be going for a better trade agreement in a post-Brexit area. And now, the Chinese seem to be basically saying, watch out, you need us more than we need you.

PATRICK CHOVANEC, CHIEF STRATEGIST, SILVER CREST ASSET MANAGEMENT: It's interesting that the Chinese are playing hardball in this way. They are playing hardball with a lot of different people. Clearly they feel they have leverage. And yes, at this point, with the Brexit vote, the British have raised the idea of a free trade agreement with China. They clearly do have leverage. But I also think that it makes sense for the British to take a little bit more skeptical view of Chinese investment. Not to say that they should have a negative view. But I think it's entirely reasonable for them to review the security issues that are involved with this kind of investment.

QUEST: It was a surprise, though, but bearing in mind, the Chinese had already sent the delegation to London for the signing ceremony. The fact that Theresa May made the decision to have a review whilst reasonable, if she decides against Hinckley and the Chinese investment, then that's going to be very difficult to repair the damage.

CHOVANEC: Well, there are a lot of things you can do to upset the Chinese. This is one deal among many. The Cameron cabinet lived in fear of offending the Chinese. And I think that they were, on the other extreme, that Osbourne in many ways was like a fan boy sometimes towards China, and they were so reluctant to engage in even completely justified criticism of China, because they wanted to court good Chinese opinion.

So I think that a little bit of a movement towards a review of these kinds of issues, look, I know from talking to people who are in a position to know in Britain that they have discovered things like back doors and software of critical infrastructure. So it's reasonable to not reject these kind of investments out of hand, because these kind of investments, it's a global economy, China is a partner in that global economy, but to take the time to actually review it makes a lot of sense to me.

QUEST: Patrick Chovanec, thank you for joining us.

CHOVANEC: Good to be with you.

QUEST: When we continue, a sporting record that's got nothing to do with the Olympics. Pogba is returning to Manchester United. The deals are ready drawing criticism because of the huge amounts of money involved. QUEST MEANS BUSINESS, we're in Washington, DC.

[16:20:00] (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

QUEST: Now he left Manchester United for just under $2 million four years ago. Now he's returning for a record-breaking contract, more than 50 times that sum. Paul Pogba, there he is. After weeks of back and forth, the 23- year-old French super star will leave Aventis and be a Red Devil once again. Pogba will wear number 6 for United. Make a note of these numbers please, because they're quite breathtaking. $116 million is his contract. It breaks the world record that was set by Gareth Bale in 2013, $116 million. Now bear in mind, he went for $2 million a couple of years ago.

The deal is being criticized for its high price. It amounts to $4 million for every league goal he's ever scored. And as some English club owners feared, it would happen in the post-Brexit world. United's pain a 12 percent premium, because the deal was done in euros and the value of sterling has plummeted.

From London is the football agent Sky Andrew. Sky Andrew, $2 million four years ago or whatever it is, $116 million in 2016. Can anything justify these sorts of sums of money?

SKY ANDREW, FOOTBALL AGENT: A player is only worth what someone is prepared to pay. We're in an era where premier clubs have the most money they've ever had, 5.14 billion in rights money. So the timing was good for Pogba. Many wanted him.

He was sold too cheaply or they paid too much. Has Pogba improved that much since they let him go?

It isn't a matter of how much Pogba has improved. It's about supply and demand. There are so many players in the world that are not as good as him. There is a massive demand for players like Pogba. And there's very little supply. So when a player like him is available, clubs all around the world are going to battle for his signature. What Manchester united have proved is even though they're not in the champions league, they've got one of the most sought-after players in the world. What it shows is that Marino, Pogba, Man United wanted to put themselves back on the map. They wanted to show people that they mean business. And newsflash, Man United are back.

QUEST: He was either sold too cheaply or they paid too much. Has Pogba improve that much since they let him go?

ANDREW: Well, it isn't a matter of how much Pogba has improved, it's about supply and demand. You know, there are so many players in the world that are not as good as him. urn:contentItem:5XBB-K6C1-JBJN-M4TC-00000-00Carlos Costa: European regulation will have "limited" effectiveness with big tech2019-10-22T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisCarlos Costa: European regulation will have "limited" effectiveness with big tech

Carlos Costa considers that banks will have to "redefine business models" and modernize information systems if they want to compete with the major platforms. Carlos Costa, Governor of Banco de Portugal, warns that it is "a matter of time" until big tech calls reach the European market and compete directly with traditional banking. And that even the regulation will have a limited capacity to contain these new "players". For the governor of the central bank, banks have to adjust to this new reality and redefine business models.


"Although the big tech are currently limited to Asia Pacific and North America, we cannot forget that they have a global vocation and that the extent to the European market is a matter of time," says Carlos Costa at the "Newsstand of the Future" conference, organised by Business.
It is the example of Google and the Revolut platform that have already obtained bank licenses to operate in Europe. With this authorisation, they took the first step to become a bank, with limited functions compared to traditional banking, but relevant to the sector.
According to the governor of the central Bank, the European regulatory framework itself "will have limited effectiveness from the point of view of containment" of the emergence of these large platforms on the market. Entities that have large data analysis capabilities, adjusting the offer of products and services to each customer's profile. "The data became more valuable than oil," the Governor notes.
In the face of this change, banks have to adapt. "There has to be an adjustment on the banks ' side," says Carlos Costa, while defending that financial institutions "will have to be flexible and fast" to respond to customer needs.
But they will also have to "redefine the business models" and bet on a "gradual transformation of the information technology system" in order to make their systems "technologically more modern, less costly and more ' user friendly '".
