Carnegie Endowment For International Peace Holds Discussion On Cyber Security

February 12, 2019 11:15 A.M.

SPEAKERS:

HOMELAND SECURITY DEPARTMENT'S CYBERSECURITY AND INFRASTRUCTURE SECURITY AGENCY DIRECTOR CHRISTOPHER KREBS NETHERLANDS

NETHERLANDS DEPUTY PRIME MINISTER KAJSA OLLONGREN

CEIP TECHNOLOGY AND INTERNATIONAL AFFAIRS PROGRAM VISITING SENIOR FELLOW DENIS MCDONOUGH

JOHNS HOPKINS SCHOOL OF ADVANCED INTERNATIONAL STUDIES STRATEGIC STUDIES PROFESSOR THOMAS RID CIPHER

BRIEF CEO SUZANNE KELLY

DHS CYBERSECURITY, AND INFRASTRUCTURE SECURITY AGENCY DEPUTY DIRECTOR MATTHEW TRAVIS

[*]MCDONOUGH: Okay, good morning everybody. Thank you for joining us. Welcome to Carnegie Endowment for International Peace. My name is Denis McDonough, a visiting Senior Fellow here at Carnegie. It's my distinct honor and great privilege to introduce to you the Deputy Prime Minister and Interior Minister of our valued ally, the Netherlands.

Minister Ollengren has been in this position of Interior Minister and Deputy Prime Minister since October of 2017. Just had two days of intensive meetings here, yesterday with our government colleagues including DHS to talk about these matters. But this morning here with us and several representatives of leading tech firms to discuss their view of this enormous challenge.

I come to this issue, not only with intense personal interest, but with a hardened experience at the front row, with a front row view of the last incident of significant Russian intervention in our elections in the 2016 elections.

So, it's with great enthusiasm that we were asked to host the Minister on her visit for this part of here visit. So, it's a great honor to have everyone here. We look very much forward to your remarks, Madam Minister. We look forward to the discussion afterwards. So, without further ado, the Deputy Prime Minister, Interior Minister of the Netherlands. Ma'am, over to you.

(APPLAUSE)

OLLENGREN: Thank you, morning. Good morning everyone. Thank you. Ladies and gentlemen, we are here to lay the foundations upon which the statesmen of Western democracies may stand and to create an atmosphere favorable to the decisions to which they may be led.

Well, you might think that would be quite an ambitious task for today, but luckily, it isn't our task, because these are not my words, but Churchill. Churchill, he said this, in 1984 the Congress of Europe, he was, of course, one of the most important founders of Europe.

And his primary objective back then in 1948, was to make it clear that the key issue was cooperation. Following the catastrophe that was World War II, what was needed more than anything was the willingness to work together because in the trenches and the face of the shell fire and the first World War, afterwards in the concentration camps and the bombed out cities, in the gulags, and while hueing for food, men and women dreamed of an undivided and free Europe.

And thanks to the sacrifice of American young men, boys, 18, 19 years old, on the beaches of Normandy, and thanks to the Martial Aid that's followed the war. Let's free Europe became a reality. And thanks to people like Winston Churchill, who through their strength, showed us the signs of hope an undivided Europe arose around us.

However, this European project, it's never complete. It's always in this state of flex. Cooperation in Europe is remarkable for its ambitions and also for its perseverance. It's a task that requires our constant attention. It requires hard work. It's a form of cooperation, that for many people, it's sort of a constant source of surprise, and sometimes even admiration.

How could it be that a group of countries, once so torn apart by war, cooperates so closely? How is it possible that countries are willing to give up their own currencies for a new single currency? How is it possible for a group of countries to voluntarily surrender part of their national sovereignty, because that's what we've done in Europe?

It's been done with a remarkable speed. Europe has rebuilt itself and has became one of the worlds largest trading partnerships in the market with 500 million consumers.

Nonetheless, the foundations on which Churchill referred are not purely economical. They do go deeper than that and they should. As a consequence of that devastating war, and regimes of terror, we understand, perhaps, better than anyone, what it means to be robbed of the most elementary fundamental of rights and basic human dignities.

So, in response, over the last 70 years, we have joined Churchill's instating that the fundamental rights of every citizen in Europe must be protected. And that's not self-evidence. It demands constant effort, certainly, in the current era, in which internal and external forces are threatening democracy and its intrinsic values.

We are faced with the major challenge of upholding those values in the modern digital domain. So, let me give you a couple of examples. Last May, the European General Data Protection Regulation, GDPR, was introduced. It's the aim of Europe, even in the digital world to continue to protect the privacy of Europeans fundamental rights of which the founders of Europe, in their age of telegrams of fixed telephones were probably not even aware.

We don't only want to take the lead in guaranteeing privacy in the digital domain, we also hope to take the lead in countering cyber threats and dis-information. Two phenomena that clearly threaten the confidence in fair and free elections.

Recent examples have made that abundantly clear. During the referendum about Brexit in the U.K., people went to the polling station with a pen because they were afraid that if they used a pencil, the mark would be rubbed out. And if they did use a pencil, the message was, you should press hard. That is worrying.

And last year we saw elections in Italy, great deal of fake news was spread by a social media. Politicians were accused of nepotism at the taxpayer's expense. And it all turned out to be incorrect. But it increased a distrust of citizens and politics.

And during the French--French Presidential elections, the then candidate, Macron, reported that his party's website were the targets of cyber-attacks. Though my visit to Washington DC, so far, has strengthened me in saying, the threats are real on both sides of the Atlantic. We need to step up our game.

Protecting elections is the core task of a government, making sure that they're free and that they're fair. However, it happens at boundering line because as government, you wish to protect the freedom of speech, the freedom of press, the freedom of debate. You don't want to sensor. You don't want to restrict that. Government is not an arbitrator of truth.

So, our approach is two-fold. Firstly, we step up our efforts to make sure that technology operates in the interest of democracy. Representatives of the big tech companies, Google, Facebook, Twitter and others, they sign the EU code of conduct against dis-information.

And our view, self-regulation of this kind is meaningful and an important first step. By these companies and they're taking responsibility. And that's very important. I think we should continue to closely monitor these developers, but we need more transparency and engagement in the light of elections that are coming up in Europe, May, this year.

Secondly, we step up to strengthen the resilience of our democratic systems. And the Dutch Government is planning a campaign to raise awareness on media literacy. The campaign will pass no judgements on the truthfulness of content. It is, instead, up to citizens to decide for themselves to be critical.

Now, the reason I'm here, as I said, is that these problems are not exclusive to the European Union, to Europe. And that is why I'm so interested in understanding your views on these issues, and to hear and to learn from your approach.

So, we need to reach out across the Atlantic. We need scientific communities, civil societies, we need all of us to help, to tackle this issue. We, representatives of a shared history, a history that stretches from Essence to Amsterdam and Washington DC. We share a civilization. That unity of values and desires presents us with new tasks and with new challenges.

And the values of that civilization are universal and they're unique. And that, in a way that they permeate our history and our solidarity with each other. The central lesson of that past is that, if Europe and America are divided, the outcome is generally tragic.

But if we stand together, then we can overcome any calamity. And perhaps, today, we could again succeed in laying foundations upon which, as Churchill said, Western democracies may stand, but this time, with the digital age. Thank you.

(APPLAUSE)

KELLY: Being here, I'd like to express my gratitude as well for Carnegie, for inviting the Cipher Brief to come and moderate. My name is Suzanne Kelly. I'm the CEO and publisher of the Cipher Brief. And we are going to have to make a slight change to the agenda today. The Deputy Minister must leave a little bit early, so we're going to wrap up the conversation around noon, but I would like to encourage a few questions.

So, to facilitate that, I'm going to go ahead and give everybody an opportunity to--I'm going to introduce you, an opportunity to answer a couple of questions and then we'll let the audience get in a few if that's alright with everyone.

So, welcome, thank you very much Madam Deputy Prime Minister. Is that correct?

OLLENGREN: Absolutely.

KELLY: Okay, well, thank you very much for those opening comments. I think it's important to focus in on what you talked about with anti-fake news. And I want to get to that in just one quick moment. I'd also like to welcome Matthew Travis. He is the first Deputy Director for DHSs Cybersecurity, and Infrastructure Security Agency.

And also, Mr. Thomas Rid who is Professor of Strategic Studies, just up the street at John's Hopkins. It's a pleasure to meet you and thank you for being here.

So, let me--let me waste no time in getting right to this. You mentioned how important the anti-fake news is. We've heard from our own intelligence community leaders just two weeks ago about how--how serious this threat is.

You launched a campaign of your own in trying to take on fake news. Tell us a little bit about what you learned from that experience and the valuable take-aways.

OLLENGREN: Well, it's too soon to tell because we're just starting it. We have elections in March, and we have the European elections in May. And this campaign, it's about--it's about awareness, media literacy. I mean, we're teaching our kids that in schools. But this is about our democracy.

So, we need to reach out to everybody. All the target groups. We know, for instance, that older people are especially vulnerable in this respect that they are, they're not used to it. So, they're an easy trap for--for fake news and disinformation.

So, really reaching out to everybody, making aware this is happening. The Netherlands is a relatively a small country, but also a very open country. And that we have not seen the amount that some other countries have seen in Eastern Europe, for instance. We shouldn't be naive. It can happen to us. And I want to be there before the elections and not afterwards, when it's too late.

KELLY: The typical conversation as well, to think through kind of what the components of that anti-fake news campaign need to include because you would like to very much say that everyone in society would be as interested as the people in this room in terms of making sure that they're educated, they're asking the right questions, they're getting the right information, they're filtering out the bad. But much, much harder as you say in actual reality.

Tell us a little bit, not about DHSs stance on this. And how you're trying to attack the issue of, not only fake news, but--but really insuring more resiliency in the--in the election process.

TRAVIS: Sure, great to be here today.

KELLY: Very small question.

TRAVIS: And thank you to Carnegie and Denis for the invitation. You know, when we look at this, we--we see it really as a two-fold problem. There is the attempts to undermine the election infrastructure, the technical manipulation of votes, compromising of election machines, voter registration roles, website of candidates and campaigns.

And that is a--kind of a physical protection problem set. But closely related that is what I call the information tax on the electorate, which gets to the mis-information and dis-information. So, within homeland security, we organize internally with two discrete teams to deal with both of those.

And our role, really, is not as the Deputy Prime minister said, and we have the same sensibility. We don't want to be the arbiters of truth. That is not the role for DHS. But what, we serve, I think in a unique position in government, our convening authority to bring in those 16 sectors of critical infrastructure, one of which is the election infrastructure industry, but also our relationships with state, local, tribal, territorial jurisdictions.

And so, being able to provide one information sharing on what we're seeing, what we can downgrade an intelligence information from the community and share it, or we can provide capacity building resources like training where we can do, on the physical side, scan networks, provide technical assistance on how secure are their networks, and even work with them to get a better sense of what's running on their networks.

And so, I think, you know, the election security challenge is not like the campaigns themselves where they come to an end and everyone exhales. We--the race continues. And candidates as you see on the news are already declared. So, we are--we are back and were still at it and--and while the mid-terms, you know, we're relatively pleased with how everything turned out. I think 2020 for us will be much more intensive given it's a Presidential election.

KELLY: Professor, you've written a number of books as well. And you've done a lot of writing on this particular issue. What do you think is missing from the national or international dialogue on how we're understanding and framing the issue?

RID: One--I think one observation just kind of misunderstanding is that dis-information invents fake news. That-that fake news is basically making up stuff. That's not really how historically dis-information and active measures, the term of art, have worked.

They work by sensing existing cleavages existing conflicts, existing conspiracies here, is for example. And then--and then pouring fuel into that fire, just making them worse. So, for example, one of the most famous examples is the AIDS theory. The theory that AIDS is an American design bio weapon built in Fort Detrick, Maryland. This is a hoax, obviously.

But the hoax existed in the early 1980s already in the activist circles. And the Soviets and Stasi together lifted it out of that corner and gave it more visibility. And then, of course, it stopped at some point in 1980--1987 and the myth continued. So, Kanye West in one his lyrics a song called, "Heard Em Say", uses that line in 2005. Is that because of the Soviet operation? We don't know.

The fact that these operations are using existing prejudices and conspiracy theories, makes them extremely hard to measure, even if you have a lot of data.

KELLY: I--and obviously, right. The influence level is extremely difficult to measure. We talked a little bit about information security and sharing information. Sharing information not only with the public, if you're talking about kind of anti-fake news, but also with each other as you prepare for elections. What were some of the key lessons learned that you feel like, Madam Minister, you can share from the last election? And preparations for the upcoming in May.

OLLENGREN: Yes, we're--we're--we're preparing for the upcoming. And I think it's--as you said, I mean, it's not--it's not a new phenomenon, but what is new is that it's now happening in the digital age with the social media.

And that has--that--that has made it a completely different ball game altogether. And I think we're now at the stage like you here in the U.S. with the--where you had an election that proved at least that was a reason for you to step up your efforts. And then you saw the mid-terms. And then you have been able to--to--to kind of were able to take away some of it.

And that is--I think we're in the same situation in Europe. We have had some elections and referendums where we know that this played a role. We cannot prove that it has actually affected the outcome. That's very difficult to prove. But we--so the awareness is much higher. And that's the reason that the European commission has made the action plan. That's the reason we have the code of conduct. That's the reason that we're talking to the tech companies and working together with the tech companies and with Academia.

And that's a big difference to two, three years ago. And for myself, also, when I first talked to the tech companies, most of them are American, of course, but stationed in Europe. And then their attitudes was a little bit, you know, searching for what can we do? What can you ask from us? What can you not ask from us?

But now their attitude is different. Now they're--because that's also affecting their credibility. So, I think that's a big change. It's a big step. But I'm sure we're not there yet. And then again, we don't know what is developing also in the field of technology.

KELLY: Seeing more cooperation--.

OLLENGREN: --Yes--.

KELLY: --which you think is a good thing--.

OLLENGREN: --Absolutely--.

KELLY: --and turn them in the right direction.

OLLENGREN: Yep.

KELLY: Let's talk about the upcoming election in 2020 because we heard Dan Coats just recently testify before the Senate that the adversaries are still out there. They're still looking to influence the election. What are you seeing? And what lessons might you be able to share from what you're seeing now?

TRAVIS: Let me start with the lessons that we drew from 2018. And I think for us it was--there were a couple of things that stand out. One, we really doubled down the investment of the partnerships with the--with the platforms.

So, the Silicon Valley companies, we engaged last Spring, went out there and met with them. And to their credits, they made the investments. They--they made the decisions to treat this as the high priority that they did. And that made a real difference because they had--we had willing partners who were not only with us throughout the campaign with whom we could share information.

With them we got a better sense of how they were attacking the problem form their end. But up until election night, when we had representatives of Twitter and Google and Facebook and Microsoft with us, either in the room or on the screen. So, that when there was some anomalies that we saw in terms of mis-information and dis-information, we could work with them.

And again, it's their role to decide what to do with that information. So, investing in those partnerships, and also, I think we--we spent a lot of time getting the media familiar with the problem set of what--how elections work, where the security risks are.

We held a table top exercise--a nationwide table top exercise where we brought the media in. So, I think, helping them to understand, again, there's tax on the election infrastructure, and then there's the information tax. Both obviously can undermine democracy. But we treat one each differently.

And I think those partnerships are what it have--have's us positioned well going into 2020. But again, as I said, I think just given the intensity and attention that Presidential elections get, I think that---that will be the--a much more pronounced effort on all fronts.

KELLY: And then also, I think an interesting question, and Professor, perhaps you can speak to this is, where--as this is an evolving process. And as you mentioned, social media's such a fast moving way to get information out there. And it's very difficult to ever bring it back once it's out.

What do you see as potential solutions to this long term? I mean, I've probably given you the hardest question up here today. But, for someone who studies it and who's seen the patterns and whose written books about this.

RID: Yeah.

KELLY: What do you see as a way for it to help?

RID: So, we've seen a number of companies as well as U.S. Government take a number of steps that are very positive and will probably make a difference, even if the difference is hard to spot because nothing happens. Success means nothing happens.

KELLY: Tough to measure.

RID: It's a bit of a difficult one to also measure. But Twitter, for example, has published it's--a lot of data from the Saint Petersburg Troll Farm, more than 10 million--around 10 million tweets. That's an extremely rich data set to work with.

So, let me just cheese out one finding. We saw in 2016 that the internet research agency amplified existing fissures and conflicts within the U.S. I would, absolutely, expect something similar to happen in 2020, and I'll say what probably, a lot of the people in the room are thinking, may not want to touch. One of the biggest vulnerabilities going into 2020, is President Trump's heated--President Trump repeatedly calling into question the legitimacy of the election itself.

Now, that is fodder for any of this information campaign because they will suddenly try to amplify that message, calling into question whether, you know, the outcome of the vote is legitimate, or not, that is ultimately. Also, a Russian goal and then here, I think we are facing an important, we, as pundits, journalists, experts, government officials, we're facing a very difficult evidential problem because any disinformation campaign that will tap into what will happen 2020, will most likely, be miniscule in effect in comparison to the (INAUDIBLE) political currents and developments.

So, when you risk exaggerating the effect of this information, we basically risk building up Russia into an adversary that is, that looks stronger and more powerful than they really are.

KELLY: So, it seems very simple to say something like this. But do we need to be looking to candidates, as well, putting responsibility on them to not be generating information that may not be 100 percent true, that may not be something that you can prove or. Do candidates need to take more responsibility in making sure the information that they're putting out is accurate?

RID: Like me to respond to that?

KELLY: That's a very difficult question because, now, we're talking politics, right? Yes, sure. I'd like all of you to respond to that, actually.

TRAVIS: We like candidates to make sure that they're practicing strong cyber hygiene measures, that their password regimes and their networks are scanned. And we, you know, we need to stand by DHS when we did throughout the 2018 cycle work with the DNC, the RNC, individual campaigns to scan their networks, to do vulnerability assessments of their electronic infrastructure.

So, that's where we take the security angle. I don't have any opinion on the question.

KELLY: I think that's a very, very simple answer from DHS, 100 percent

RID: I would just say this. The, given the history of statements that, and I'm sorry, this is a political thing to say but it has to be said. Given the past, the history of statements from Donald Trump, on the legitimacy of outcomes of election, you know, the systems rigged in 2016, but he continued along those lines. I think it is an important conversation to have among, among elected members of Congress, especially in the Senate, possibly among former Presidents of the United States, people who have the weight in a public discussion to step into a very fragile moment on election nights, on November 9, when possibly, the question comes up, are we dealing with a legitimate election, here, and what happened.

So, we need, in a situation like this, there are only a very few people who can de-escalate and create the perception of stability. And I think it is crucial to have this conversation ahead of time. And sure, it's happening already, but I think it's an important one to have.

KELLY: You're looking at academics and you're looking media institutions to be able to weigh in on the impact of something, whether or not it's intentional or not, in terms of the message. There's an impact there.

RID: I think we're really looking at Senators and elected officials.

KELLY: And how do you look at this from outside the U.S. and think what lessons are we seeing that we can take away?

OLLONGREN: Well, there are many lessons. First, perhaps, let me go into this issue, also, not of course, in the American situation but in the Netherlands. I think the principle of a democracy is that you have freedom of speech and the exchange of ideas. And so, politicians, any candidate should feel free to say whatever he or she wants to say and to present his or her truth, even if it's not true. Because that's political debate.

But if the system is working, then you have independent journalism that takes care of that, that can ask questions. You have the other politicians, the opponents, that will also take care of that issue. So, I think that's the kind of democracy that I feel very strongly about, that you can have this political debate.

What you don't want is influence that you don't really see what's coming from elsewhere. It has a different purpose, it's coming from other countries with the purpose to destabilize. I agree, completely, what was said just now. It's not--it's not just about being true or not true, fake or not fake. It's about destabilizing our society.

KELLY: That's an understanding that the adversaries have that opportunity.

OLLONGREN: Because we are an open society. We present with them with that opportunity because we want to be open society.

KELLY: Exactly right.

TRAVIS: And we'll just add to this that I do think there's a basic level of responsibility for the citizenry, to be a citizen of the United States. You know, read whatever you want but know what you're reading. And so, we had some, you know, some phrases, "Think before you link." And people just scrolling down with no regard to the source of the information that they're reading.

Now, that's not necessarily, being as a responsible citizen, I think we all need. And so, there, you know, this is a, you know, collective effort to make sure that democracy can still thrive. It's not just the government, it's not just the social media company, it's not just the candidates. It's the electorate, as well.

KELLY: Massive collective effort, which is why I think everybody realizes how incredibly difficult but important it is. Do we have questions from the audience? I'd like to share some of the time. Here. Do we have a microphone? Yeah, we do, it's coming. If I could just have you, kindly, tell us who you are and where you're from, that would be great.

QUESTION: I have a question for Professor Rid. Rid, did I say that right? That is the idea which I have not heard before. And so, I'm, of having trusted voices speak on election night about the legitimacy of the results of the campaign. On one hand, that's a very appealing idea to me and on the other hand, I think about poor General Powell who went up before the United Nations and testified that there were weapons of mass destruction, after having been briefed by the intelligence communities that there were.

So, I wonder how you can--what system could possibly reassure a Jimmy Carter and a George W. Bush that they were comfortable saying those things?

RID: I think you may be in a better position to answer that question. And me, I'll just say briefly, some of the work that has been done at DHS and elsewhere is creating visibility, if I'm understanding you and some of your colleagues correctly, into potential attacks, cyber-attacks against election infrastructure.

And of course, attack against the debates, public debates are visible by default. Sometimes, not openly visible but you can see them. So, it's not a problem that will appear in a fluff on election night. It is a problem that will slowly arise and then we'll see it.

TRAVIS: Yeah, I would just say that we see ourselves as trying to improve people's ability to make risk informed decisions. And so, everything we do is geared towards promoting and sharing information so that, whether it's the candidates, whether it's the parties, whether it's social media platforms or the public, that they can understand the threats and vulnerabilities into what they're --what they're reading, so.

I don't think I have an answer to your central question but that's all I'll say on that.

KELLY: Understanding the threat in a timely, I would think is equally as important because it kind of loses its effectiveness weeks later. Question.

QUESTION: Thank you very much. What was the AmericaRussian service--thank you very much for being here, today. I think Netherlands were probably first, one of the first international victims of fake new with all this dozens of fake versions of shot down of MH17, five years ago. And my question is related to MH17. Did you discuss, did you discuss it, here, in the United States, maybe requesting some help or something else? What is the nature of talks of government of Netherlands with Russians because, now, we have statements, of a Russian foreign ministry confirming these talks, still denying any responsibility?

Do you think that Russia is responsible for shooting down MH17 and what's the roadmap for bringing those who did it to justice? Thank you.

OLLONGREN: Those are lots of questions but very important questions. It's true that the, we have been affected by this information concerning the MH17 so, that was vulnerability in our society, this terrible disaster that happened. It has affected, also, our relationship with Russia, ever since. And it still does.

We have two tracks that are still ongoing and so, for the criminal law, there is an investigation team that has researched what has happened and it has found proof that there was a Russian buck, missile that shot it down. And so, the proof is there but the court hearings still have to happen.

And there is the international track. We are holding Russia responsible, together with, very young with another affected country. And in the context of that process there will be talks with Russia. And that is what you have been reading about. They are being prepared today.

And your question if it's been part of the discussions that I've had here, yes, because I' made 17 for instance, it's very--extremely important. We have always depended on the cooperation of the U.S. and still are. That is very important to us. There was one American citizen on board. But aside from that, the U.S. has always proven itself a very valuable partner.

And it's important for us to keep them up to date and to keep them involved.

QUESTION: Hi there. My name is Nicholas Turpstrom (PH), a student at Calvin College, Grand Rapids, Michigan, studying here, interning at the Cato Institute.

I had a quick question for, perhaps, Mr. Rid and Mr. Travis. By and large, would you say that the things that we've been seeing are more undermining on social media, the elections, or more directed at candidate support, especially, say in 2016 and 2018. Which of the two types of quote, unquote, fake news are more popular?

RID: I think what we've seen in 2016, on certain kinds social media, disinformation campaigns and I'll make a, sort of, bold, big statement, here. We tend to overestimate the effect of these campaigns. The most effective component of the 2016 election interference was the hack and leak of, ultimately, John Podesta's Email via wiki leaks, not anything that happened on Twitter and Facebook.

So, while it is important to work with the data that we have, really have to be very cautious in assessing effects. You know, keep in mind the internet research agency in St. Petersburg was exposed by Russian domestic investigative journalists, four weeks after it was created, and it continued to be an ongoing story. It's a very unprofessionally run operation.

TRAVIS: I would just say that I think it's a mistake to think that the influence campaigns are only centered around elections. And in fact, what we see from bad actors is an attempt to, you know, whether it's sewing discord or, you know rabble rousing in any, any issue that is going to try to divide and polarize society.

So, you see it throughout the year, unrelated to elections in terms of trying to win influence and make socially divisive issues ever more so. And that's, I think, the greater threat to the societies become more and more polarized than, you know, adding that element to try to accelerate that polarization is one I think we all need to be on the lookout for.

KELLY: That's a tool. That's a great point. Yes, sir, back to you now.

QUESTION: My name is Roger (INAUDIBLE), I work with private equity in the technology sector. And my question is a little bit more philosophical. Thirty years ago, when the law of the internet was first coming together, the basic principle was that a website operator was liable and responsible. The internet industry was liable and responsible for any content that they posted. And the comparison was that they were like a publisher. The newspaper is responsible for the letters to the editor that they publish, even though they didn't write them, and a newspaper is responsible for the op-ed articles that they publish, even though they didn't write them.

So, there was a chain of liability and responsibility. There was enormous pushback against that. And by the mid '90s, the basic legal structure was that internet providers were not responsible for the content. They were more like a telephone company which has no responsibility for the words that people speak over the phone or a post office that has no responsibility for the content of the letters that are mailed.

In the last ten years, we've seen a significant reversal of that, that's a very topical, very specific. Well, they're not, internet companies are not responsible for the content, but they are responsible for making sure that child predation content is not posted. They are responsible for making sure that human trafficking content is not posted. But if we go down the path of saying that internet companies are responsible for making sure that news is not posted by somebody who has nefarious intentions and lies from a country that I don't like, where does this stop?

I mean, why, why can't the people of Saudi Arabia say, you can't have content that's blasphemous or the people of Mississippi say you can't have content that's nudity. You know, where do we draw the line between responsibility to surveil and filter out stuff you don't want?

KELLY: Right, it's a great point. Sorry to cut you off. I'm being a little bit mindful of time, but I think your question is, whose responsibility, ultimately, is this monitor. We've struggled with this for quite a while. What are your thoughts on that and then, I'm going to have each of you give us some closing thoughts before we have to wrap up?

OLLONGREN: Okay, maybe the Professor, first on this issue because I think that's-

KELLY: --Right up your alley.

RID: Well, I'm not sure I have something really intelligent to say in response to this being sort of familiar, content management question. And instead, I'll use the opportunity to just briefly say something to Minister. I think the, I just wanted to make sure that you hear that the work and especially, the work that you've done there has been going, really over decades, in the field of exposing hostile operations via neutron bomb operation in 1979, comes to mind where your country was at the forefront of a major election and a major interference operation.

And of course, again, the work and the context as I mentioned to the team but also, exposing some of the GRU hacking operations more recently with, you know, pictures, you know. Very commendable and impressive work, so, well done.

OLLONGREN: Thank you.

KELLY: Alright, shall we, I think that's a great question. I think it's a big one to grasp. Do you have comments on, either of you, on that question?

TRAVIS: I think, for one, the Department of Homeland Security enthusiastically supports the first amendment. So, we have, absolutely, no interest in--and I appreciate the question itself. I think if you look at the Mueller indictments on the Russian troll factory, those are developed foreign influence, right. So, we're talking about foreign speech trying to influence U.S. elections.

There are laws that, you know, prohibit that. That's an issue, there. The rest of it, I think is great issues to take up in academia and other public fora.

KELLY: Any final thoughts?

OLLONGREN: Lots of them. But I think we have to wrap up.

KELLY: Yeah, what should we walk away with from this?

OLLONGREN: Yes, what should we walk--I think to step up our efforts to work together. I was very inspired by visiting DHS, yesterday. It was very inspiring. I think some, we're doing already in the Netherlands, but I think we have to do more of it. And I also, I want to leave you with the concern that we have, free speech is the essence of everything.

And so, we always have to respect that and, if you have that as your fundamental position, then all the other things you can do in a coordinated and cooperative manner. I mean, we need each other. Not only the tech and the platforms, mostly American companies. But as I've been talking to them, I understand, also, that they have more--they're trying to understand our culture in Europe and our way of dealing with these issues.

And also, we understand that you're one country and Europe is 28 countries, 27 in a couple of weeks' time. And they're all different. They have diverse and different cultures, different judicious, different histories, with Russia, for instance. So, we have to keep all of that in mind but still find ways to work together.

TRAVIS: As the phrase was in the Navy, that when you're driving the ships, vigilance is the eternal price for safety. I think vigilance is the eternal price for democracy. I think it's incumbent upon all of us to understand what we're reading, where it's coming from and this notion of a collective effort from the social media platforms, from government, from the citizenry, there are placed to go to find out where this is coming from.

The Atlantic Council, The Alliance for Securing Democracy, do great work, publicly available on showing. And not from the government on where some of these global ne'er do wells are what they're putting out there. And I think the message that we have from DHS is, we want to continue to work with all partners from the states, from the localities, from the technology companies but also, the citizens need to be more vigilant.

KELLY: And that's one of DHS's biggest challenges, is the education component, too, right. Professor, any final thoughts?

RID: No, I think we've had enough fun.

KELLY: Well, I'd like to thank each of you, again. I know that the Minister has to move on to appointments, this afternoon, but thank you, so much, for sharing some of this. I think we could have dug in to any of these issues and talked extensively any one of them.

But thank you and thank you, again, for the time you gave for allowing us to be here and to you for coming and listening and asking questions.

(APPLAUSE)

urn:contentItem:5N6T-7XY1-F0JP-W4XW-00000-00Carnegie's new digital revolution2017-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 28Carnegie's new digital revolutionRICHARD GLUYAS, TECHNOLOGY, EXCLUSIVE

Maile Carnegie's crystal ball is telling her it's going to be different this time.

Unlike previous banking insurgencies, which promised revolution but barely disturbed the status quo, the threat posed by the industry's digital Visigoths is both significant and real.

It's time to engage or face commercial irrelevance.

"I wouldn't have come into this role unless I felt it was mission critical," ANZ's new digital boss tells The Weekend Australian.

When Carnegie peers 20 years into the future, the blurred images she discerns include two major banks instead of four, a tech giant or two in the form of an Apple, Google or Amazon, and a handful of fintech companies that somehow had the stamina and wherewithal to last the distance.

If you assume ANZ is one of the two major-bank survivors, which, of course, she does, that means only one of Commonwealth Bank, Westpac and National Australia Bank will emerge with its pillar status intact.

Three weeks ago, Carnegie met with the ANZ board's subcommittee on digital business and technology to present the strategy she had crafted with other senior executives.

It was a blueprint to strengthen and reposition the bank so it can take full advantage of the opportunities that emerge in the digital era.

The key elements include a dramatic simplification of a typical incumbent bank that's become mired in complexity, cranking up the innovation engine, identifying core capabilities that can remake the bank, and targeting new and different revenue pools.

Carnegie smiles and clams up when asked for more detail about the latter - there's only so much she's prepared to give away to -rivals.

She stresses, however, that nothing less than a cultural transformation of the bank is required, which is where the digital halo she acquired from Google comes into play.

While it will certainly help ANZ that its new digital boss ran Google in Australia and New Zealand for four years, it's misguided to suggest that the search giant's famed innovative culture can easily be transplanted to a legacy bank.

"One of the wonderful things in my previous role was to experience the almost scientific way that Google thought about culture," she says.

"It feels like a very nebulous concept, but it's an outcome from a number of very clear and discrete choices that you make and Google worked through all that in a very clear and methodical way." ANZ, she says, began its transformation before she joined the bank in June last year.

Chief executive Shayne Elliott had taken over from predecessor Mike Smith on the first day of 2016, and a year or so later chief risk officer Nigel Williams is the only member of the senior leadership team who is in the same job.

The bank had set down some very clear digital parameters, like the Apple Pay deal, more of which later.

Carnegie's contribution will draw from Google, a longer period in fast-moving consumer goods at Proctor & Gamble, and her own leadership style.

So far, there has been far too much to do to even contemplate Google-ising the workplace.

"That's probably much to the disappointment of a lot of people," she says with a laugh.

"I've seen a lot of organisations mimic (Google's) execution, like: 'We've put the ping-pong tables in so now we can innovate!' But it just doesn't work." As to her own style, Carnegie has raised a few eyebrows in the terribly staid, mostly proper and male-dominated world of banking by occasionally padding around the office in bare feet.

She's amused that, in her nine months or so at ANZ, this is one of the stories that has evidently piqued a certain level of interest, acknowledging that her approach to leadership is "slightly different" to her colleagues.

"I tend to call a spade a shovel," she says. "I understand at some level that I need to dress like a banker so I will metaphorically put the grey flannel suit on, but at my core I'm a girl from North Epping (in Sydney's northwest) whose parents are teachers.

"At the end of the day I don't take myself too seriously, just like Shayne, who is introducing a more humble and curious culture. But I don't take my shoes off assuming it will drive cultural change!" If there's a single deal that's emblematic of ANZ's approach to the digital age, it's the partnership with the Apple Pay digital wallet struck in April last year.

It's emblematic because it involves an acceptance by ANZ that collaboration is the best model to give customers what they actually want.

It might be a perception of -superior functionality, or it might just come down to the Apple brand, but whatever it is ANZ had to confront the reality that it doesn't always have the answers.

The contrast with the three other major banks could not be more stark. In July, they pitched the competition regulator for an exemption to collectively negotiate access to the near-field communications antenna on the iPhone so they could provide their own digital wallets without relying on Apple Pay for payments processing. The ACCC kyboshed those hopes in its final ruling, announced yesterday.

Carnegie accepts you can "absolutely make the argument" that Apple should open up its infrastructure and collaborate with the banks.

"But the right lens to look through in this kind of issue is what the customer wants," she says.

"You have to have the humility to say: 'We have a digital wallet and the customers should want ours more, but they just don't'." For Carnegie, Apple Pay represents a digital demarcation line that separates the institutions that are destined to win in the 21st century. She argues that the accelerating pace of change means that open systems will triumph over closed systems "every single day", and tweeted as much earlier this month.

"For any single institution in the world to honestly believe they're going to be able to meet the needs of their customers at the pace of change that we're only just starting to see is ludicrous," Car-negie says.

"So I will always back an open system, but that requires a degree of maturity on both sides, including the banks, because we'll be collaborating with people one day and turning around and competing against them the next.

"The fact that our customers love Apple Pay doesn't mean we will never work again on our own digital wallet." It begs the question: what happens to the banks that refuse to collaborate; where the impulse to own and control everything that comes into their orbit is irresistible?

Maybe they just disappear inside an app, or wither away.

Carnegie makes the point that even Amazon is opening physical branches, and has been mentioned in connection with a possible takeover of the incumbent US bank Capital One.

"But your point is a valid one - the future for a bank that doesn't make the transition is not a happy one," she says.

"That said, there are parts of banking that are very technically difficult, such as credit risk and regulator management, and the big tech companies don't want to do that.

"Some banks might think they don't need to own the customer relationship."Clearly, ANZ is not one of them.

urn:contentItem:5N77-BVD1-JD3N-52FX-00000-00Carnegie's new digital revolution2017-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisBUSINESSPg. 25Carnegie's new digital revolutionRICHARD GLUYAS, TECHNOLOGY, EXCLUSIVE

Maile Carnegie's crystal ball is telling her it's going to be different this time.

Unlike previous banking insurgencies, which promised revolution but barely disturbed the status quo, the threat posed by the industry's digital Visigoths is both significant and real.

It's time to engage or face commercial irrelevance.

"I wouldn't have come into this role unless I felt it was mission critical," ANZ's new digital boss tells The Weekend Australian.

When Carnegie peers 20 years into the future, the blurred images she discerns include two major banks instead of four, a tech giant or two in the form of an Apple, Google or Amazon, and a handful of fintech companies that somehow had the stamina and wherewithal to last the distance.

If you assume ANZ is one of the two major-bank survivors, which, of course, she does, that means only one of Commonwealth Bank, Westpac and National Australia Bank will emerge with its pillar status intact.

Three weeks ago, Carnegie met with the ANZ board's subcommittee on digital business and technology to present the strategy she had crafted with other senior executives.

It was a blueprint to strengthen and reposition the bank so it can take full advantage of the opportunities that emerge in the digital era.

The key elements include a dramatic simplification of a typical incumbent bank that's become mired in complexity, cranking up the innovation engine, identifying core capabilities that can remake the bank, and targeting new and different revenue pools.

Carnegie smiles and clams up when asked for more detail about the latter - there's only so much she's prepared to give away to -rivals.

She stresses, however, that nothing less than a cultural transformation of the bank is required, which is where the digital halo she acquired from Google comes into play.

While it will certainly help ANZ that its new digital boss ran Google in Australia and New Zealand for four years, it's misguided to suggest that the search giant's famed innovative culture can easily be transplanted to a legacy bank.

"One of the wonderful things in my previous role was to experience the almost scientific way that Google thought about culture," she says.

"It feels like a very nebulous concept, but it's an outcome from a number of very clear and discrete choices that you make and Google worked through all that in a very clear and methodical way." ANZ, she says, began its transformation before she joined the bank in June last year.

Chief executive Shayne Elliott had taken over from predecessor Mike Smith on the first day of 2016, and a year or so later chief risk officer Nigel Williams is the only member of the senior leadership team who is in the same job.

The bank had set down some very clear digital parameters, like the Apple Pay deal, more of which later.

Carnegie's contribution will draw from Google, a longer period in fast-moving consumer goods at Proctor & Gamble, and her own leadership style.

So far, there has been far too much to do to even contemplate Google-ising the workplace.

"That's probably much to the disappointment of a lot of people," she says with a laugh.

"I've seen a lot of organisations mimic (Google's) execution, like: 'We've put the ping-pong tables in so now we can innovate!' But it just doesn't work." As to her own style, Carnegie has raised a few eyebrows in the terribly staid, mostly proper and male-dominated world of banking by occasionally padding around the office in bare feet.

She's amused that, in her nine months or so at ANZ, this is one of the stories that has evidently piqued a certain level of interest, acknowledging that her approach to leadership is "slightly different" to her colleagues.

"I tend to call a spade a shovel," she says. "I understand at some level that I need to dress like a banker so I will metaphorically put the grey flannel suit on, but at my core I'm a girl from North Epping (in Sydney's northwest) whose parents are teachers.

"At the end of the day I don't take myself too seriously, just like Shayne, who is introducing a more humble and curious culture. But I don't take my shoes off assuming it will drive cultural change!" If there's a single deal that's emblematic of ANZ's approach to the digital age, it's the partnership with the Apple Pay digital wallet struck in April last year.

It's emblematic because it involves an acceptance by ANZ that collaboration is the best model to give customers what they actually want.

It might be a perception of -superior functionality, or it might just come down to the Apple brand, but whatever it is ANZ had to confront the reality that it doesn't always have the answers.

The contrast with the three other major banks could not be more stark. In July, they pitched the competition regulator for an exemption to collectively negotiate access to the near-field communications antenna on the iPhone so they could provide their own digital wallets without relying on Apple Pay for payments processing. The ACCC kyboshed those hopes in its final ruling, announced yesterday.

Carnegie accepts you can "absolutely make the argument" that Apple should open up its infrastructure and collaborate with the banks.

"But the right lens to look through in this kind of issue is what the customer wants," she says.

"You have to have the humility to say: 'We have a digital wallet and the customers should want ours more, but they just don't'." For Carnegie, Apple Pay represents a digital demarcation line that separates the institutions that are destined to win in the 21st century. She argues that the accelerating pace of change means that open systems will triumph over closed systems "every single day", and tweeted as much earlier this month.

"For any single institution in the world to honestly believe they're going to be able to meet the needs of their customers at the pace of change that we're only just starting to see is ludicrous," Car-negie says.

"So I will always back an open system, but that requires a degree of maturity on both sides, including the banks, because we'll be collaborating with people one day and turning around and competing against them the next.

"The fact that our customers love Apple Pay doesn't mean we will never work again on our own digital wallet." It begs the question: what happens to the banks that refuse to collaborate; where the impulse to own and control everything that comes into their orbit is irresistible?

Maybe they just disappear inside an app, or wither away.

Carnegie makes the point that even Amazon is opening physical branches, and has been mentioned in connection with a possible takeover of the incumbent US bank Capital One.

"But your point is a valid one - the future for a bank that doesn't make the transition is not a happy one," she says.

"That said, there are parts of banking that are very technically difficult, such as credit risk and regulator management, and the big tech companies don't want to do that.

"Some banks might think they don't need to own the customer relationship." Clearly, ANZ is not one of them.more reports P28

urn:contentItem:60WS-NVK1-DYRJ-01WR-00000-00Carr Says CDA S. 230 Rules Aim to Push Back on Concentrations of Power2020-09-17T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSCarr Says CDA S. 230 Rules Aim to Push Back on Concentrations of Power

The goal of the FCC Communications Decency Act Section 230 proceeding is to "push back on concentrations of power" held by big tech companies, said FCC Commissioner Brendan Carr during a virtual Lincoln Network Q&A Wednesday. Carr said his push for "light-touch regulation" represents a growing shift among conservatives, and existing conservative Washington think tanks are dominated by "abject corporatism" and opposition to all regulation. "My approach to net neutrality is consistent with my approach to big tech," Carr said. "It's easy to say 'let's not change anything,'" Carr said. "This is not simply competition in a free market; this is taking advantage of a landscape skewed by law to favor their business model."

Carr's calls for regulation of large tech companies are different from those of Democrats such as Sen. Elizabeth Warren, D-Mass., because he's not looking for drastic moves such as breaking them up, he said. The Ajit Pai FCC took the light-touch path on net neutrality rules for ISPs by incorporating FTC enforcement and transparency requirements, Carr said. "We need to be leaning on transparency to get the result we want." Carr said he would like users to have control over whether their feeds are fact-checked.

Big tech is "unique" in terms of the power it currently wields without accompanying regulation, Carr said. "There's nothing like it in terms of the power it holds over our daily lives." The regulations he's proposing won't harm U.S. tech companies much or lead to domination of the space by Chinese tech companies, he said. If tech companies are going to have the benefits of the special liability protections Section 230 provides them, they should be held accountable, he said.

Carr said the goal of reform proposals isn't to neutralize online platforms politically or aid one side's voices. He rejected comparisons of the 230 proposal to FCC content rules that conservatives have traditionally opposed. "The analogy between fairness doctrine and 230 is not an apt one," Carr said: Additional transparency rules would aid platforms like Twitter because they would remove the "black box" around company actions seen by some as rooted in political bias.

The rhetoric on the Section 230 proposal is "overblown," Carr said. He said the changes wouldn't affect platforms' ability to act against online calls to violence or obscenity but would focus on political speech. He said the FCC has the authority to pursue the proposal, though he conceded several times the going would be difficult. "I understand there are challenges," he said. "We can hold these platforms more accountable."

Carr said the support for the proposed rule changes exceeded his expectations, noting backing from AT&T and legislators such as Sen. Lindsey Graham, R-S.C. The docket has gotten 7,000 comments, he said.

urn:contentItem:5YX4-X531-JC8G-82HF-00000-00Carr Urges Facebook to Stop Policing Speech; Some Question His Opining2020-05-13T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisTOP NEWSCarr Urges Facebook to Stop Policing Speech; Some Question His Opining

Facebook should take a hands-off approach to content moderation, FCC Commissioner Brendan Carr told us in arguing the company's new oversight board injects political bias and lets the platform avoid responsibility. Carr criticized the board in a series of tweets, calling it Facebook "speech police" and arguing most members have left-leaning bias. Facebook and several board members didn't comment Tuesday.

Some industry experts and observers agreed in other interviews with some of Carr's points. The commissioner has taken heat in the recent weeks over his focus on China and other issues that some argue are outside his agency's purview (see 2004240045). Others argued Facebook should be more active in moderating to stop the spread of hate content, which has been rampant on filterless platforms like 4chan. Some noted the FCC has no jurisdiction over speech on social media platforms, a point that Carr addressed in Monday's interview.

Carr warned against biased and fallible participants making content moderation decisions, particularly about political speech. He urged Facebook to get "out of the speech police business altogether." He suggested the company turn off its "bias filters," giving users the option to have unfiltered feeds.

"Unless you want Facebook to turn into 4chan, setting and enforcing reasonable limits is appropriate," said Information Technology and Innovation Foundation Vice President Daniel Castro. "So the oversight board is a good move because it establishes an independent and transparent process to start adjudicating decisions and upholding values like free speech." The board appears to be "a diverse and thoughtful group of people" structured to operate with independence, he said.

It's unclear why Carr is spending time on this issue because there's no FCC jurisdiction, said Free Press co-CEO Jessica Gonzalez. It's critical for Facebook to moderate its platform to prevent the spread of hate groups and white supremacists, she said: The company has a responsibility to protect users from abuse, and it hasn't done a good enough job so far. It's unclear whether the panel will help, but she said she doesn't want to "trash it" yet.

Carr acknowledged the jurisdiction-related pushback. "I don't envision a regulatory role for the FCC," he said, noting it's not an issue he has raised with Chairman Ajit Pai or other commissioners. He intended to highlight the selections Facebook made, he said.

The content moderation approach, whether done under the umbrella of Facebook or the company operating through a so-called supreme court, is a "fraught no-win path," Carr said. "It's pretty plain that they've stood this board up as a way to sort of pass the buck and say, 'Hey, it's not us. It's this oversight board.' You really can't have it both ways."

Gun safety advocate Andy Parker, a frequent critic of big tech and its use of Section 230 of the Communications Decency Act (see 2002200049), agreed Facebook created this body to improve its reputation. It's "purely cosmetic," and nothing is going to happen until Congress amends or revokes Section 230, he said.

The board could be a useful adjunct to Facebook's own obligations, but Section 230 is really the issue, said Excolo Law's Keith Altman: Child pornography doesn't proliferate on Facebook because the platform is held accountable for such content. The company should face the same accountability for terror-related content, he argued.

The platform should focus less on human intervention and more on technology for locating harmful content, said Coalition for a Safer Web Vice President-Content Moderation Eric Feinberg. Now, he said, the tech player is relying on a reactionary, whack-a-mole approach. He said that means a lot of material slips through in foreign languages.

Twenty members are on the oversight board, originating from the U.S., Australia, Cameroon, France, Israel, the U.K., Kenya, Brazil, Denmark, Hungary, Colombia, Indonesia, Taiwan, Pakistan, Senegal, India and Yemen. The U.S. members (see personals section, May 7) are co-Chair Michael McConnell, Stanford Law School; Evelyn Aswad, University of Oklahoma College of Law; Jamal Greene, Columbia Law School; Pamela Karlan, Stanford Law School; and John Samples, Cato Institute.

As the computing industry grapples with its role in society, many people, both(https://gzconsulting.org/2018/06/04/salesforce-there-is-a-crisis-of-trust-concerning-data-privacy-and-cybersecurity/) in the field and (   https://www.wsj.com/articles/in-praise-of-hierarchy-1515175338) outside it, are talking about a (   https://www.bostonglobe.com/ideas/2018/03/22/computer-science-faces-ethics-crisis-the-cambridge-analytica-scandal-proves/IzaXxl2BsYBtwM4nxezgcP/story.html) crisis of (   https://www.wsj.com/articles/the-culture-of-deathand-of-disdain-1507244198) ethics.

There is a massive rush to hire (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/10/21/opinion/who-will-teach-silicon-valley-to-be-ethical.html) chief ethics officers , retool (   https://theconversation.com/programmers-need-ethics-when-designing-the-technologies-that-influence-peoples-lives-100802) codes of professional ethics and (   https://news.harvard.edu/gazette/story/2019/01/harvard-works-to-embed-ethics-in-computer-science-curriculum/) teach ethics to students . But as a (   https://scholar.google.com/citations?user=DQaARsgAAAAJ&hl=en) scholar of computing 6 and a teacher of (   https://www.cs.rice.edu/~vardi/COMP301-2019.pdf) a course on computing , ethics and society at Rice University 6 I am skeptical of the assumptions that what ails technology is a lack of ethics, and that the best fix is to teach technologists about ethics.

Instead, in my view, the solution is government action, which aims at balancing regulation, ethics and markets. This isn't a radical new idea: It's how society treats cars and driving.

Consider, for instance, the Ford Model T, the first mass-produced and mass-consumed automobile. Its debut in 1908 launched the automobile age, a time of great mobility 6 and widespread death. Car crashes (https://www.who.int/gho/road_safety/mortality/en/) kill more than a million people worldwide each year 6 but the fatality rate per mile driven (   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Transportation_safety_in_the_United_States) has been dropping almost since the first Model T rolled off the assembly line.

The reason for that improving safety record is not that people learning to drive studied the ethics of responsible and safe driving. Rather, they were taught, and tested on, the rules of the road, in order to obtain a driving license. Other regulations (https://www.fhwa.dot.gov/programadmin/standards.cfm) improved how roads were built , required car makers to adopt (   https://www.npr.org/2015/10/16/449090584/why-arent-auto-safety-standards-universal) new safety features , mandated (   https://www.nerdwallet.com/blog/insurance/car-insurance/) accident (   https://www.nerdwallet.com/blog/insurance/car-insurance/) insurance , and o(   https://www.nhtsa.gov/laws-regulations/impaired-driving) utlawed drunk driving and (   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Texting_while_driving) other unsafe behaviors. I believe a similar approach 6 regulation, in addition to ethics education for technologists, as well as market competition 6 is needed today to make modern technology safe for society as a whole.

Flaws in the basic business model

In the 1980s, internet pioneers adopted a philosophy that "(https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Information_wants_to_be_free) information wants to be free " 6 so website owners didn't charge readers for access to the content. Instead, internet companies used advertising to support their efforts. That led them to collect personal data on their users and offer micro-targeted advertising to make money, which social scientist Shoshana Zuboff calls "(   https://www.publicaffairsbooks.com/titles/shoshana-zuboff/the-age-of-surveillance-capitalism/9781610395694/) surveillance capitalism ."

This business model is (https://www.macrotrends.net/stocks/charts/GOOG/alphabet/revenue) enormously profitable , so it's unlikely internet companies will abandon it on their own as a result of ethical qualms. Even in the face of (   https://techcrunch.com/2018/10/24/apples-tim-cook-makes-blistering-attack-on-the-data-industrial-complex/) blistering critiques and (   https://theconversation.com/understanding-facebooks-data-crisis-5-essential-reads-94066) Facebook's Cambridge Analytica scandal, the massive profits are compelling.

The real problem with surveillance capitalism is not that it is unethical 6 which I believe it is 6 but that it is completely legal in most countries. It is unreasonable to expect for-profit corporations to avoid profitable businesses that are legal. In my view, it is not enough to simply criticize internet companies' ethics. If society finds the surveillance business model offensive, then the remedy is not an ethical outrage, but making laws and regulations that govern it, or even prevent it altogether.

Of course, public policy cannot be divorced from ethics. Selling human organs (https://insights.ovid.com/crossref?an=00007890-201709000-00016) is banned in the U.S . in part because society finds it ethically repugnant to profit from life itself. But the ban is enforced by laws, not by an ongoing ethics debate. As Chief Justice Earl Warren remarked: "I(   https://www.brainyquote.com/quotes/earl_warren_112607) n civilized life, law floats in a sea of ethics ."

Regulation has benefits

For decades, the information-technology industry has (https://www.wired.com/story/the-case-against-elon-musk-will-chill-innovation/) successfully lobbied a gainst attempts to legislate or regulate it, arguing that "(   https://bigthink.com/peter-thiel-regulation-stifles-innovation) regulation stifles innovation ." Of course, that assumes all innovation is good. It has become evidently clear that this is not always the case: Some of the internet giants' (   https://theconversation.com/facebook-is-killing-democracy-with-its-personality-profiling-data-93611) innovation has harmed democratic society in the U.S. and around the world.

In fact, one purpose of regulation is to chill certain kinds of innovation 6 specifically, those that the public finds wrong, distasteful or unhelpful to the advancement of society. Regulation can also encourage innovation in ways society deems beneficial. There is no question that regulations on the automobile industry encouraged innovation in (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Automotive_safety) safety and (   https://www.ucsusa.org/clean-vehicles/fuel-efficiency/fuel-economy-basics.html) fuel efficiency.

Some members of Congress have proposed a number of (https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4620765-PlatformPolicyPaper.html#document/p1) ambitious (   https://www.documentcloud.org/documents/4620765-PlatformPolicyPaper.html#document/p1) plans to tackle (   https://theconversation.com/weaponized-information-seeks-a-new-target-in-cyberspace-users-minds-100069) information warfare , consumer protection, competition in digital technology and the role of artificial intelligence in society. But much simpler 6 and more widely supported 6 rules could make a huge difference for individual customers and society as a whole.

For instance, federal regulators could require software terms and licenses include plain language that's easily understood by anyone 6 perhaps modeled on the longstanding "(https://www.sec.gov/rules/final/33-7497.txt) plain English rule " for corporate financial filings to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Laws or rules could also require companies to (   https://finance.yahoo.com/news/need-federal-law-protecting-consumers-data-leaks-195017782.html) disclose data breaches quickly, both to officials and the public at large. That might even spark innovation as firms increase their efforts to prevent and detect network intrusions and data theft. Another relatively easy opportunity would be to regulate automated judicial decision systems, including requiring that they not be deployed before passing an independent audit showing that they are (   https://www.propublica.org/article/machine-bias-risk-assessments-in-criminal-sentencing) fair and unbiased.

Those straightforward regulations could pave the way for thinking and talking about whether and how to regulate (https://www.cnn.com/2018/12/17/tech/big-tech-too-big-tim-wu/index.html) the sizes of these big technology firms . But rule-making need not start with the hardest problems 6 there's plenty to do that most people would agree on right away.

The bottom line is that technology advances have been moving (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Moore%27s_law) very fast , while public policy has lagged behind. It is time for public policy to catch up with technology. If technology is driving the future, society should do the steering.

(https://theconversation.com/profiles/moshe-y-vardi-242448) Moshe Y. Vardi is a professor of Computer Science, Rice University.

urn:contentItem:5VR5-7YJ1-F03R-N391-00000-00Cars Are Regulated For Safety - Why Not Information Technology?2019-03-25T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:33:14ZLexisNexisCars Are Regulated For Safety - Why Not Information Technology?

Mar 25, 2019( International Business Times News: http://www.ibtimes.com Delivered by Newstex) As the computing industry grapples with its role in society, many people, bothin the field[1]andoutside[2] it, are talking about acrisis[3]ofethics[4]. There is a massive rush to hirechief ethics officers[5], retoolcodes of professional ethics[6]andteach ethics to students[7]. But as ascholar of computing[8]- and a teacher ofa course on computing[9], ethics and society at Rice University - I am skeptical of the assumptions that what ails technology is a lack of ethics, and that the best fix is to teach technologists about ethics. Instead, in my view, the solution is government action, which aims at balancing regulation, ethics and markets. This isn't a radical new idea: It's how society treats cars and driving. Consider, for instance, the Ford Model T, the first mass-produced and mass-consumed automobile.

Its debut in 1908 launched the automobile age, a time of great mobility - and widespread death. Car crashes killmore than a million people worldwide each year[10]- but the fatality rate per mile drivenhas been dropping[11]almost since the first Model T rolled off the assembly line. Chart: The Conversation, CC-BY-ND Source: U.S. National Highway Transportation Safety Administration Photo: The Conversation The reason for that improving safety record is not that people learning to drive studied the ethics of responsible and safe driving. Rather, they were taught, and tested on, the rules of the road, in order to obtain a driving license. Other regulationsimproved how roads were built[12], required car makers to adoptnew safety features[13], mandatedaccident[14] insurance[15], andoutlawed drunk driving[16]andother unsafe behaviors.[17] I believe a similar approach - regulation, in addition to ethics education for technologists, as well as market competition - is needed today to make modern technology safe for society as a whole. Flaws in the basic business model In the 1980s, internet pioneers adopted a philosophy that 'information wants to be free[18]' - so website owners didn't charge readers for access to the content. Instead, internet companies used advertising to support their efforts. That led them to collect personal data on their users and offermicro-targeted advertisingto make money, which social scientist Shoshana Zuboff calls 'surveillance capitalism[19].' This business model isenormously profitable[20], so it's unlikely internet companies will abandon it on their own as a result of ethical qualms. Even in the face ofblistering critiques[21]andFacebook's Cambridge Analytica[22]scandal, the massive profits are compelling. Chart: The Conversation, CC-BY-ND Source: MacroTrends Photo: The Conversation The real problem with surveillance capitalism is not that it is unethical - which I believe it is - but that it is completely legal in most countries. It is unreasonable to expect for-profit corporations to avoid profitable businesses that are legal. In my view, it is not enough to simply criticize internet companies' ethics. If society finds the surveillance business model offensive, then the remedy is not an ethical outrage, but making laws and regulations that govern it, or even prevent it altogether. Of course, public policy cannot be divorced from ethics. Selling human organsis banned in the U.S[23].in part because society finds it ethically repugnant to profit from life itself. But the ban is enforced by laws, not by an ongoing ethics debate. As Chief Justice Earl Warren remarked: 'In civilized life, law floats in a sea of ethics[24].' Regulation has benefits For decades, the information-technology industry hassuccessfully lobbieda[25]gainst attempts to legislate or regulate it, arguing that 'regulation stifles innovation[26].' Of course, that assumes all innovation is good. It has become evidently clear that this is not always the case: Some of the internet giants'innovation has harmed democratic society[27]in the U.S. and around the world. A general view on the lined up cars of the 5th Bodensee Klassik rallye at Festspielhaus in Bregenz, Austria, May 5, 2016. Photo: Jan Hetfleisch/Getty Images In fact, one purpose of regulation is to chill certain kinds of innovation - specifically, those that the public finds wrong, distasteful or unhelpful to the advancement of society. Regulation can also encourage innovation in ways society deems beneficial. There is no question that regulations on the automobile industry encouraged innovation insafety[28]andfuel efficiency[29]. Some members of Congress have proposed a number ofambitious[30] plans[31]to tackleinformation warfare[32],consumer protection,competition in digital technologyand therole of artificial intelligencein society. But much simpler - and more widely supported - rules could make a huge difference for individual customers and society as a whole. For instance, federal regulators could require software terms and licenses include plain language that's easily understood by anyone - perhaps modeled on the longstanding 'plain English rule[33]' for corporate financial filings to the U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission. Laws or rules could also require companies todisclose data breaches[34] quickly, both to officials and the public at large. That might even spark innovation as firms increase their efforts to prevent and detect network intrusions and data theft. Another relatively easy opportunity would be to regulate automated judicial decision systems, including requiring that they not be deployed before passing an independent audit showing that they arefair and unbiased[35]. Those straightforward regulations could pave the way for thinking and talking about whether and how to regulatethe sizes of these big technology firms[36]. But rule-making need not start with the hardest problems - there's plenty to do that most people would agree on right away. The bottom line is that technology advances have been movingvery fast[37], while public policy has lagged behind. It is time for public policy to catch up with technology. If technology is driving the future, society should do the steering. Moshe Y. Vardi[38] is a professor of Computer Science, Rice University.
